<subject>Nonfiction television programs</subject> 
<description>"Russia covers an area of over 10 million square miles and crosses 11 different time zones. In this gigantic land it is possible to experience the widest and most dramatic range of landscapes on earth from the vast plains in the west to unspoiled forests and northern Arctic tundra." -- container.</description>

<title>The U.S. and &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> hearing before the Committee on International Relations, House of Representatives, One Hundred Fifth Congress, second session.</title> 
<creator>United States. Congress. House. Committee on International Relations.</creator> 
<contributor>ProQuest [Firm]</contributor> 
<publisher>Washington : U.S. G.P.O. : For sale by the U.S. G.P.O., Supt. of Docs., Congressional Sales Office</publisher>

i/enc:UTF-8&ctx_tim=2017-04-01T12%3A05%3A53IST&url_ver=Z39.88-2004&url_ctx_fmt=infofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rfr_id=info:sid/primo.exlibrisgroup.com:primo3-Journal-ndu_aleph&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:book&rft.genre=&rft.atitle=&rft.jtitle=&rft.btitle=My%20mission%20to%20Russia.&rft.aulast=Buchanan&rft.auinit=&rft.auinit1=&rft.auinitm=&rft.ausuffix=&rft.au=Buchanan,%20George,%20Sir&rft.aucorp=&rft.volume=&rft.issue=&rft.part=&rft.quarter=&rft.ssn=&rft.spage=&rft.epage=&rft.pages=&rft.artnum=&rft.issn=&rft.eissn=&rft.isbn=0405030088&rft.sici=&rft.coden=&rft_id=info:doi/&rft.object_id=&svc_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:sch_svc&svc.fulltext=yes&rft.eisbn=&rft_dat=<ndu_aleph>000128607</ndu_aleph><grp_id>73536243</grp_id><oa></oa>&rft_id=info:oai/&req.language=]]></sear:openurlfulltext><sear:linktoholdings>OVP</sear:linktoholdings><sear:linktouc>http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=isbn%3A0405030088</sear:linktouc><sear:lln01/></sear:LINKS></sear:DOC><sear:DOC <display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>Authoritarian &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> analyzing post-Soviet regime changes</title> 
<creator>Vladimir Gelʹman 1965-</creator> 
<contributor>Project Muse.</contributor> 
<publisher>Baltimore, Maryland : Project Muse</publisher> 
<publisher>Pittsburgh, Pa. : University of Pittsburgh Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2015</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780822980933; $$CISBN $$V0822980932</identifier> 
<subject>Democratization -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Regime change -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Authoritarianism -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<description>Russia today represents one of the major examples of the phenomenon of "electoral authoritarianism" which is characterized by adopting the trappings of democratic institutions (such as elections, political parties, and a legislature) and enlisting the service of the country's essentially authoritarian rulers. Why and how has the electoral authoritarian regime been consolidated in Russia? What are the mechanisms of its maintenance, and what is its likely future course? This book attempts to answer these basic questions. Vladimir Gel'man examines regime change in Russia from the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 to the present day, systematically presenting theoretical and comparative perspectives of the factors that affected regime changes and the authoritarian drift of the country. After the fall of the Soviet Union, Russia's national political elites aimed to achieve their goals by creating and enforcing of favorable "rules of the game" for themselves and maintaining informal winning coalitions of cliques around individual rulers. In the 1990s, these moves were only partially successful given the weakness of the Russian state and troubled post-socialist economy. In the 2000s, however, Vladimir Putin rescued the system thanks to the combination of economic growth and the revival of the state capacity he was able to implement by imposing a series of non-democratic reforms. In the 2010s, changing conditions in the country have presented new risks and challenges for the Putin regime that will play themselves out in the years to come.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VSeries in Russian and East European studies.</relation>

<lds30>Series in Russian and East European studies.</lds30>

<title>Authoritarian &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> analyzing post-Soviet regime changes /</title> 
<description>Russia today represents one of the major examples of the phenomenon of "electoral authoritarianism" which is characterized by adopting the trappings of democratic institutions (such as elections, political parties, and a legislature) and enlisting the service of the country's essentially authoritarian rulers. Why and how has the electoral authoritarian regime been consolidated in Russia? What are the mechanisms of its maintenance, and what is its likely future course? This book attempts to answer these basic questions. Vladimir Gel'man examines regime change in Russia from the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 to the present day, systematically presenting theoretical and comparative perspectives of the factors that affected regime changes and the authoritarian drift of the country. After the fall of the Soviet Union, Russia's national political elites aimed to achieve their goals by creating and enforcing of favorable "rules of the game" for themselves and maintaining informal winning coalitions of cliques around individual rulers. In the 1990s, these moves were only partially successful given the weakness of the Russian state and troubled post-socialist economy. In the 2000s, however, Vladimir Putin rescued the system thanks to the combination of economic growth and the revival of the state capacity he was able to implement by imposing a series of non-democratic reforms. In the 2010s, changing conditions in the country have presented new risks and challenges for the Putin regime that will play themselves out in the years to come.</description>

<notes>Includes bibliographical references (pages 155-200) and index.</notes> 
<abstract>Russia today represents one of the major examples of the phenomenon of "electoral authoritarianism" which is characterized by adopting the trappings of democratic institutions (such as elections, political parties, and a legislature) and enlisting the service of the country's essentially authoritarian rulers. Why and how has the electoral authoritarian regime been consolidated in Russia? What are the mechanisms of its maintenance, and what is its likely future course? This book attempts to answer these basic questions. Vladimir Gel'man examines regime change in Russia from the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 to the present day, systematically presenting theoretical and comparative perspectives of the factors that affected regime changes and the authoritarian drift of the country. After the fall of the Soviet Union, Russia's national political elites aimed to achieve their goals by creating and enforcing of favorable "rules of the game" for themselves and maintaining informal winning coalitions of cliques around individual rulers. In the 1990s, these moves were only partially successful given the weakness of the Russian state and troubled post-socialist economy. In the 2000s, however, Vladimir Putin rescued the system thanks to the combination of economic growth and the revival of the state capacity he was able to implement by imposing a series of non-democratic reforms. In the 2010s, changing conditions in the country have presented new risks and challenges for the Putin regime that will play themselves out in the years to come.</abstract>

<addata><aulast>Feldbrugge</aulast><aufirst>F. J. M.</aufirst><addau>Feldbrugge, F. J. M</addau><btitle>Russia, Europe, and the rule of law</btitle><seriestitle>Law in Eastern Europe ; 56</seriestitle><date>2007</date><risdate>2007.</risdate><isbn>9789004155336</isbn><isbn>9004155333</isbn><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><cop>Leiden ; Boston</cop><pub>Martinus Nijhoff</pub><format>book</format><seriestitle>Law in Eastern Europe ; no. 56</seriestitle><seriestitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</seriestitle><oclcid>319492145</oclcid><isbn>9789047411642</isbn><isbn>9047411641</isbn><abstract>Russia has gone through a process of radical political and socio-economic transformation. The legal system has reflected the various stages of this process and has also been an agent in moving it forward. This book looks at the role law has played in the transformation of Russia and evaluates the legal achievements of the Putin administration.</abstract><risdate>c2007.</risdate><notes>Includes biblioographical references and index.</notes><cop>Leiden, The Netherlands ; Boston [Mass.]</cop></addata>

<title>Letters from &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>.</title> 
<creator>Vigor, Mrs., 1699-1783.</creator>

<creationdate>1970</creationdate>

<sourcerecordid>$$V002246326$$Ondu_aleph002246326</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V002391776$$Ondu_aleph002391776</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph002246326</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph002391776</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg21048986</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph002246326</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph002391776</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph002246326</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph002391776</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph002246326</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph002391776</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01002246326$$Ondu_aleph002246326</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01002391776$$Ondu_aleph002391776</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>The NATO-&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> partnership : a marriage of convenience or a troubled relationship?</title> 
<creator>Stephen Blank 1950-</creator> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle Barracks, PA : Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</publisher> 
<creationdate>2006</creationdate> 
<format>x, 92 p. ; 23 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1584872594; $$CISBN $$V9781584872597</identifier> 
<subject>North Atlantic Treaty Organization -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Security, International</subject> 
<description>Four years after the NATO-Russia Council came into being, it represents a picture in ambivalence and incomplete realization of partnership. This monograph focuses on the Russian side of this growing estrangement. It finds the Russian roots of this ambivalence or alienation in the increasingly visible manifestations of an autocratic and neo-imperial Russian state and foreign and defense policy. These strong trends in Russian policy inhibit the formation of a genuine security partnership that can provide for Eurasian security in the face of multiple contemporary threats. Indeed, it is debatable whether Russia really wants a comprehensive partnership with NATO. The author examines Russia's perspectives in this relationship and this growing estrangement between the West and Russia, tracing it to trends in Russian domestic, defense, and foreign policies.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VU.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</relation>

This monograph focuses on the Russian side of this growing estrangement. It finds the Russian roots of this ambivalence or alienation in the increasingly visible manifestations of an autocratic and neo-imperial Russian state and foreign and defense policy. These strong trends in Russian policy inhibit the formation of a genuine security partnership that can provide for Eurasian security in the face of multiple contemporary threats. Indeed, it is debatable whether Russia really wants a comprehensive partnership with NATO. <display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the current state of arms control</title> 
<contributor>Stephen Blank 1950-</contributor> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle, PA : Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</publisher> 
<creationdate>2012</creationdate> 
<format>vi, 102 p. ; 23 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1584875402; $$CISBN $$V9781584875406</identifier> 
<subject>Arms control -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Nuclear arms control -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Nuclear weapons -- Government policy -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Nuclear nonproliferation -- Government policy -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>United States -- Foreign relations -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Foreign relations -- United States</subject> 
<subject>Treaty between the United States of America and the Russian Federation on Measures for the Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms [2010 April 8]</subject> 
<description>Arms control remains the central issue in U.S.-Russian relations for many reasons, including the respective capabilities of these two states and their consequent responsibility for preventing both nuclear proliferation and the outbreak of war between them. The bilateral relationship is usually directly proportional to the likelihood of their finding common ground on arms control. To the extent that they can find such ground, chances for an agreement on what have been the more intractable issues of regional security in Eurasia and the Third World grow, and the converse is equally true. The chapters in this volume focus on Russian developments in arms control in the light of the so-called New Start Treaty signed and ratified in 2010 by Russia and the United States in Prague, Czech Republic.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VSSI monograph.</relation>

<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the current state of arms control /</title> 
<description>Arms control remains the central issue in U.S.-Russian relations for many reasons, including the respective capabilities of these two states and their consequent responsibility for preventing both nuclear proliferation and the outbreak of war between them. The bilateral relationship is usually directly proportional to the likelihood of their finding common ground on arms control. To the extent that they can find such ground, chances for an agreement on what have been the more intractable issues of regional security in Eurasia and the Third World grow, and the converse is equally true. The chapters in this volume focus on Russian developments in arms control in the light of the so-called New Start Treaty signed and ratified in 2010 by Russia and the United States in Prague, Czech Republic.</description> 
<subject>Treaty between the United States of America and the Russian Federation on Measures for the Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (2010 April 8)</subject>

<subject>New START Treaty (2010)</subject> 
<subject>New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (2010)</subject>

<notes>Includes bibliographical references.</notes> 
<abstract>Arms control remains the central issue in U.S.-Russian relations for many reasons, including the respective capabilities of these two states and their consequent responsibility for preventing both nuclear proliferation and the outbreak of war between them. The bilateral relationship is usually directly proportional to the likelihood of their finding common ground on arms control. To the extent that they can find such ground, chances for an agreement on what have been the more intractable issues of regional security in Eurasia and the Third World grow, and the converse is equally true. The chapters in this volume focus on Russian developments in arms control in the light of the so-called New Start Treaty signed and ratified in 2010 by Russia and the United States in Prague, Czech Republic.</abstract> 
<cop>Carlisle, PA</cop> 
<pub>Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</pub>

<title>Countering urban terrorism in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the United States proceedings of a workshop</title> 
<creator>National Research Council [U.S.]. Committee on Counterterrorism Challenges for &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the United States.</creator> 
<contributor>Glenn E. Schweitzer 1930-</contributor> 
<contributor>A. Chelsea Sharber</contributor> 
<contributor>Rossiĭskai͡a akademii͡a nauk.</contributor> 
<publisher>Washington, DC : National Academies Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>c2006</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource.</format> 
<subject>Terrorism -- Russia [Federation] -- Prevention</subject> 
<subject>Terrorism -- United States -- Prevention</subject> 
<language>eng</language> 
<lds01>"In cooperation with the Russian Academy of Sciences."</lds01> 
<lds01>"Proceedings of the third U.S.-Russian interacademy workshop on the general theme of countering terrorism ... held in Washington, D.C., at the end of January and beginning of February 2005"--P. vii.</lds01> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph003729835</lds02> 
<lds03>Report of U.S.-Russian working group on energy vulnerabilities / Aleksandr Yu. Kudrin ... [et al.] -- Report of U.S.-Russian working group on transportation vulnerabilities / Mortimer L. Downey ... [et al.] -- Report of U.S.-Russian working group on cyberterrorism issues / Anita K. Jones ... [et al.] -- Cybersecurity and urban terrorism : vulnerability of the emergency responders / Anita K. Jones, Linton Wells III, Michael Wolin -- News and terrorism : communicating in a crisis / Randy Atkins -- Problems of urban terrorism in Russia / Konstantin V. Frolov -- Terrorist acts in Moscow : experience and lessons in eliminating their consequences / Aleksandr Yu. Kudrin -- Critical integration and coordination issues in urban security / George Bugliarello -- Special characteristics of firefighting in urban areas / Nikolay P. Kopylov -- A decision informatics approach to urban emergency management / James M. Tien -- Efforts of Russian ministries in implementing measures to prevent acts of terrorism / Sergey G. Vasin -- Safety and security in megacities / Lewis M. Branscomb -- The role of science and technology in homeland security and countering terrorism : overview of key activities at the national academies / Wm. A. Wulf -- Does the emergence of insurgencies provide lessons for terrorism? / Robert McC. Adams -- Unauthorized use of radiation sources : measures to prevent attacks and mitigate consequences / Leonid Bolshov ... [et al.] -- Other dimensions of radiological terrorism / John F. Ahearne -- Biological terrorism : regional preparedness / Russ Zajtchuk -- On the events in Beslan / Gennady Kovalenko -- Measuring progress, or lack thereof, in combating terrorism / Raphael Perl -- On efforts to counter international terrorism in the Russian Federation and possible areas of U.S.-Russian cooperation in this area / Valetin A. Sobolev -- Cybercrime and the training of specialists to combat it in Russia / Nikolay V. Medvedev -- Methodology for assessing the risks of terrorism / Nikolay A. Makhutov -- Appendixes. Agenda and list of participants ; Russian Academy of Sciences-U.S. National Academies Joint Committees on Countering Terrorism / Glenn E. Schweitzer.</lds03>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>Politics and economics in Putin's &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<contributor>Stephen Blank 1950- [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute, publisher.</contributor> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Press, publisher.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle, PA : Strategic Studies Institute and U.S. Army War College Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2013</creationdate> 
<format>viii, 210 pages ; 23 cm.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1584875984; $$CISBN $$V9781584875987</identifier> 
<subject>Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Political stability -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Failed states -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Economic policy -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Economic conditions -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Strategic aspects</subject> 
<description>In one way or another, the papers included in this monograph, from the Strategic Studies Institute's annual conference on Russia in May 2012, all point to the internal pathologies that render Russian security a precarious affair at the best of times. As the editor suggests, the very fact of this precariousness makes Russia an inherently unpredictable and even potentially dangerous actor, not necessarily because it will actively attack its neighbors, though we certainly cannot exclude that possibility, but rather because Russia may come apart trying to play the role of a great power in Eurasia or elsewhere. As we all know, that outcome happened in 1917 and in 1989-91, with profound implications for international security and U.S. interests.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<availlibrary>$$INDU$$LHESB$$1General Collection$$2(DK 510.76 .P65 2013 )$$Savailable$$31$$40$$5N$$60$$XNDU50$$YHESB$$ZGEN</availlibrary> 
<lds01>"December 2013."</lds01> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph003616495</lds02> 
<lds03>1. Introduction : Politics and economics in Putin's Russia : what do they mean for the U.S. Army? / Stephen J. Blank -- 2. Russian economic reform 2012 : "dèjà vu all over again" / Steven Rosefielde -- 3. Economic reform under Putin 2.0 : will petrodollars suffice to keep the ship afloat? / Stefan Hedlund -- 4. Authoritarianism and modernization in Russia : Is Russia ka-Putin? / Harley Balzer -- 5. Russia as a pole of power : Putin's regional integration agenda / Janusz Bugajski.</lds03>

<search>
<creatorcontrib>Stephen J. Blank, editor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Stephen,  Blank  1950-  editor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Blank, S  editor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Army War College (U.S.). Strategic Studies Institute, publisher.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Army War College (U.S.). Press, publisher.</creatorcontrib> 
<title>Politics and economics in Putin's &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> /</title> 
<description>In one way or another, the papers included in this monograph, from the Strategic Studies Institute's annual conference on Russia in May 2012, all point to the internal pathologies that render Russian security a precarious affair at the best of times. As the editor suggests, the very fact of this precariousness makes Russia an inherently unpredictable and even potentially dangerous actor, not necessarily because it will actively attack its neighbors, though we certainly cannot exclude that possibility, but rather because Russia may come apart trying to play the role of a great power in Eurasia or elsewhere. As we all know, that outcome happened in 1917 and in 1989-91, with profound implications for international security and U.S. interests.</description> 
<subject>Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Political stability Russia (Federation).</subject> 
<subject>Failed states Russia (Federation).</subject> 
<subject>Russia (Federation) Politics and government 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia (Federation) Economic policy 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia (Federation) Economic conditions 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia (Federation) Strategic aspects.</subject> 
<subject>Pujing, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Putin, Volodymyr, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Putin, Wladimir Wladimirowitsch, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Putinas, Vladimiras, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Poutine, Vladimir Vladimirovitch, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Путин, Владимир Владимирович, 1952-</subject> 
<general>Strategic Studies Institute and U.S. Army War College Press,</general>

<toc>1. Introduction : Politics and economics in Putin's Russia : what do they mean for the U.S. Army? / Stephen J. Blank -- 2. Russian economic reform 2012 : "dèjà vu all over again" / Steven Rosefielde -- 3. Economic reform under Putin 2.0 : will petrodollars suffice to keep the ship afloat? / Stefan Hedlund -- 4. Authoritarianism and modernization in Russia : Is Russia ka-Putin? / Harley Balzer -- 5. Russia as a pole of power : Putin's regional integration agenda / Janusz Bugajski.</toc>

<addata>
<aulast>Blank</aulast> 
<aufirst>Stephen,</aufirst> 
<addau>Blank, Stephen</addau> 
<btitle>Politics and economics in Putin's Russia</btitle> 
<date>2013</date> 
<risdate>[2013]</risdate> 
<isbn>1584875984</isbn> 
<isbn>9781584875987</isbn> 
<format>book</format> 
<ristype>BOOK</ristype> 
<notes>Includes bibliographical references.</notes> 
<abstract>In one way or another, the papers included in this monograph, from the Strategic Studies Institute's annual conference on Russia in May 2012, all point to the internal pathologies that render Russian security a precarious affair at the best of times. As the editor suggests, the very fact of this precariousness makes Russia an inherently unpredictable and even potentially dangerous actor, not necessarily because it will actively attack its neighbors, though we certainly cannot exclude that possibility, but rather because Russia may come apart trying to play the role of a great power in Eurasia or elsewhere. As we all know, that outcome happened in 1917 and in 1989-91, with profound implications for international security and U.S. interests.</abstract> 
<oclcid>868082348</oclcid> 
</addata>

<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the European Union : the sources and limits of "special relationships"</title> 
<creator>Cynthia A. Roberts</creator> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle Barracks, PA : Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</publisher> 
<creationdate>2007</creationdate> 
<format>ix, 133 p. : charts, map ; 23 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1584872780; $$CISBN $$V9781584872788</identifier> 
<subject>European Union -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>European Union -- Membership</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Foreign relations</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<description>Russia and the West have avoided renewed confrontation despite many post Cold War crises, but illiberal trends in Russia rule out any prospect of developing a mutual agenda for closer integration. Russian engagement with the leading Euro-Atlantic institutions on a special, but still subordinate, nonmember basis remains a clever yet suboptimal substitute. Such relationships, as this monograph about Russia and the European Union explains, tend to produce shallow collaboration, symbolic summitry and costly standoffs. Closer cooperation is blocked by an ongoing dispute over terms, which is rooted in asymmetries in power, ambivalent preferences, uncertainty about the distributional costs and benefits of deeper engagement, and Russia's continued unwillingness or inability to lock-in the liberal domestic structures necessary to make credible commitments. Moscow's renewed self-confidence and geopolitical ambitions, bolstered by sustained economic growth and high energy prices, complicate the bargaining and further strain these special relationships which persist for lack of a realistic, superior alternative.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VThe U.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</relation>

<search><title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the European Union : the sources and limits of "special relationships" /</title><description>Russia and the West have avoided renewed confrontation despite many post Cold War crises, but illiberal trends in Russia rule out any prospect of developing a mutual agenda for closer integration. Russian engagement with the leading Euro-Atlantic institutions on a special, but still subordinate, nonmember basis remains a clever yet suboptimal substitute. Such relationships, as this monograph about Russia and the European Union explains, tend to produce shallow collaboration, symbolic summitry and costly standoffs. Closer cooperation is blocked by an ongoing dispute over terms, which is rooted in asymmetries in power, ambivalent preferences, uncertainty about the distributional costs and benefits of deeper engagement, and Russia's continued unwillingness or inability to lock-in the liberal domestic structures necessary to make credible commitments. Moscow's renewed self-confidence and geopolitical ambitions, bolstered by sustained economic growth and high energy prices, complicate the bargaining and further strain these special relationships which persist for lack of a realistic, superior alternative.</description><subject>European Union Russia (Federation).</subject><subject>European Union Membership.</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Foreign relations.</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Politics and government 1991-</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Foreign relations 1991-</subject><general>(OCoLC)85823851</general><general>OCoLC85823851</general><general>85823851</general><recordid>ndu_aleph002270535</recordid><recordid>002270535</recordid><recordid>2270535</recordid><isbn>1584872780</isbn><isbn>9781584872788</isbn><toc>The roots of special relationships: bargaining problems -- Partial integration vs. full integration -- International and domestic incentives to reform: the successful European integration model -- Prospects for anchoring post-Communist neighbors outside the EU -- The framework of relations: building a special relationship in lieu of Russia's membership in EU -- Russia's approach to partnership: underlying commitment problems -- Russia-EU partnership under Putin: tactical success and strategic stalemate -- The long and winding road to nebulous common spaces -- Economic asymmetries and energy interdependence -- Mutual ambivalence about the Europeanization and integration of Russia -- Russia's multi-vector strategy and the mixes appeal of "Euro-east" -- Integration with the West: an idea whose time keeps coming -- Conclusions.</toc><addtitle>The U.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</addtitle><scope>HESB</scope><lsr01>HESB GEN</lsr01><lsr01>HESB General Collection</lsr01><lsr03>The U.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</lsr03><lsr05>U 413. A66 U534 2007</lsr05><lsr05>U413.A66U5342007</lsr05><lsr05>U413. A66 U534 2007 :</lsr05><lsr08>[Carlisle Barracks, PA] :</lsr08><lsr09>00000024483851</lsr09><lsr30>The U.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</lsr30><creatorcontrib>Cynthia A.  Roberts</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Roberts, C</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Cynthia A. Roberts.</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Army War College (U.S.). Strategic Studies Institute.</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>United States. Army War College. Strategic Studies Institute</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Strategic Studies Institute (Army War College)</creatorcontrib><title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the European Union the sources and limits of "special relationships" /</title><description>More than 15 years after the collapse of the Soviet Union and two decades after the last Soviet President, Mikhail Gorbachev, raised hopes that Russia would liberalize and join a common European home, Moscow again resorts to authoritarian means amid the continuing absence of a mutual agenda for Russia's integration into Western institutions. Since the end of the Cold War, Russia and the West have averted renewed confrontation but managed only to craft a series of half-formed, suboptimal partnerships -- with the European Union (EU), the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), and the Group of 7 -- in which Russia is neither anchored by democratic rules nor fully excluded by Western institutions. These "special relationships," which have been often turbulent , are now seriously strained by Russia's stronger geopolitical position, boosted by sustained high economic growth and market power in energy, and newly-emboldened rulers, who seek to renegotiate terms. This monograph, which focuses on Russia and the EU, explains why such special relationships tend to produce shallow collaboration, symbolic summitry, and costly standoffs. It underscores the bargaining problems which block closer cooperation in areas of mutual interest, from managing energy interdependence, instability in the Balkans, and nuclear proliferation in the Middle East, to negotiating a new partnership and cooperation agreement. The ongoing disputes are over terms, not just enforcement, and rooted in asymmetries in power, uncertainty about the distributional costs and benefits of engagement, and mistrust generated by continued unwillingness or inability to lock-in the liberal domestic structures necessary for credible commitments or converge to European norms.</description><subject>European Union Foreign relations Russia (Federation).</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Foreign relations European Union countries.</subject><general>Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War <title>Russia and the European Union : the sources and limits of "special relationships" /</title> 
<creationdate>2007</creationdate> 
<author>Roberts, Cynthia A.</author> 
<lso01>2007</lso01>

<frbr><t>1</t><k1>$$Kroberts cynthia a$$AA</k1><k3>$$Krussia and the european union the sources and limits of "special relationships"$$AT</k3></frbr>
<delivery><institution>$$VNDU$$Ondu_aleph002270535</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ondu_aleph002270535</delcategory><institution>$$VNDU$$Ondu_aleph002289660</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ondu_aleph002289660</delcategory></delivery>

<addata><btitle>Russia and the European Union : the sources and limits of "special relationships"</btitle><seriestitle>The U.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</seriestitle><risdate>2007.</risdate><isbn>1584872780</isbn><isbn>9781584872788</isbn><notes>Includes bibliographical references (p. 108-133).</notes><abstract>Russia and the West have avoided renewed confrontation despite many post Cold War crises, but illiberal trends in Russia rule out any prospect of developing a mutual agenda for closer integration. Russian engagement with the leading Euro-Atlantic institutions on a special, but still subordinate, nonmember basis remains a clever yet suboptimal substitute. Such relationships, as this monograph about Russia and the European Union explains, tend to produce shallow collaboration, symbolic summitry and costly standoffs. Closer cooperation is blocked by an ongoing dispute over terms, which is rooted in asymmetries in power, ambivalent preferences, uncertainty about the distributional costs and benefits of deeper engagement, and Russia's continued unwillingness or inability to lock-in the liberal domestic structures necessary to make credible commitments. Moscow's renewed self-confidence and geopolitical ambitions, bolstered by sustained economic growth and high energy prices, complicate the bargaining and further strain these special relationships which persist for lack of a realistic, superior alternative.</abstract><cop>Carlisle Barracks, PA]</cop><oclcid>85823851</oclcid><aulast>Roberts</aulast><aufirst>Cynthia A.</aufirst><au>Roberts, Cynthia A</au><btitle>Russia and the European Union the sources and limits of "special relationships"</btitle><seriestitle>U.S. and Russia, regional security issues and interests</seriestitle><date>2007</date><risdate>[2007]</risdate><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references (p. 86-133).</notes><abstract>More than 15 years after the collapse of the Soviet Union and two decades after the last Soviet President, Mikhail Gorbachev, raised hopes that Russia would liberalize and join a common European home, Moscow again resorts to authoritarian means amid the continuing absence of a mutual agenda for Russia's integration into Western institutions. Since the end of the Cold War, Russia and the West have averted renewed confrontation but managed only to craft a series of half-formed, suboptimal partnerships -- with the European Union (EU), the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), and the Group of 7 -- in which Russia is neither anchored by democratic rules nor fully excluded by Western institutions. These "special relationships," which have been often turbulent , are now seriously strained by Russia's stronger geopolitical position, boosted by sustained high economic growth and market power in energy, and newly-emboldened rulers, who seek to renegotiate terms. This monograph, which focuses on Russia and the EU, explains why such special relationships tend to produce shallow collaboration, symbolic summitry, and costly standoffs. It underscores the bargaining problems which block closer cooperation in areas of mutual interest, from managing energy interdependence, instability in the Balkans, and nuclear proliferation in the Middle East, to negotiating a new partnership and cooperation agreement. The ongoing disputes are over terms, not just enforcement, and rooted in asymmetries in power, uncertainty about the distributional costs and benefits of engagement, and mistrust generated by continued unwillingness or inability to lock-in the liberal domestic structures necessary for credible commitments or converge to European norms.</abstract><cop>Carlisle, PA</cop><pub>Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</pub><oclcid>85813228</oclcid></addata>

<sourcerecordid>$$V004452265$$Ondu_aleph004452265</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V003142931$$Ondu_aleph003142931</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V000303688$$Obci_aleph000303688</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph004452265</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003142931</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vbci_aleph$$Obci_aleph000303688</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg67158707</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph004452265</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003142931</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VBCI01$$Obci_aleph000303688</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph004452265</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003142931</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Obci_aleph000303688</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph004452265</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003142931</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Obci_aleph000303688</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01004452265$$Ondu_aleph004452265</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003142931$$Ondu_aleph003142931</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VBCI01000303688$$Obci_aleph000303688</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> : the challenges of transformation</title> 
<contributor>Piotr Dutkiewicz [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>Dmitriĭ Trenin [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>JSTOR [Organization].</contributor> 
<publisher>New York : New York University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2011</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xviii, 491 pages) : illustrations..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780814785010 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V0814785018 (electronic bk.) (discovery)</identifier> 
<subject>Post-communism -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Economic conditions -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Economic policy -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<description>In Russia a group of leading Russian intellectuals and social scientists join with top researchers from the world to examine the social, political, and economic transformation of Russia. This timely and important book of original essays makes clear that neither politics nor economics alone holds the key to Russia's future, presenting critical perspectives on challenges facing Russia, both in its domestic policies and in its international relations. It also explores how global order - or disorder - may develop over the coming decades.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VPossible futures series ; v. 4.</relation>

Colton -- The sociology of post-reform Russia / Mikhail K. Gorshkov -- Elites: the choice for modernization / Leonid Grigoriev -- Education for an innovative Russia / Nur Kirabaev -- Health and healthcare in Russia today and tomorrow / Oleg Atkov and Guzel Ulumbekova -- The imaginary curtain / Roderic Lyne -- What kind of a Europe for what kind of Russia / Alexander Rahr -- The Obama administration's "reset button" for Russia / Andrew C. Kuchins -- Russia: the eastern dimension / Bobo Lo -- Russia and the newly independent states of Central Asia: relations transformed / Rustem Zhangozha -- Of power and greatness / Dmitri Trenin -- Russia and the West: toward understanding / Vladimir I. <type>book</type> 
<title>Women and transformation in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<contributor>Aino Saarinen [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>Kirsti Ekonen [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>V. I. Uspenskai͡a [editor]</contributor> 
<publisher>London ; New York : Routledge, Taylor &amp; Francis Group</publisher> 
<creationdate>2014, ©2014</creationdate> 
<format>xii, 240 pages ; 24 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780415841313; $$CISBN $$V0415841313; $$CISBN $$V0203766482; $$CISBN $$V9780203766484</identifier> 
<subject>Feminism -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<description>This book looks at Russian women's mobilization and agency during the two periods of transformation, the turn of the 19th-20th century and the 20th - 21st century. Bringing together the parallels between the two great transformations, it focuses on both the continuities and breaks and, importantly, it shows them from the grassroots point of view, emphasizing the local factor. Chapters show the international and transnational aspects of Russian women's agency of different spheres and different historical periods. The book goes on to raise new research questions such as the evaluation and comparison of Soviet society and contemporary Russia from the point of view of gender and women's possibilities in society. --Amazon.com.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VRoutledge studies in the history of Russia and Eastern Europe ; 18.</relation> 
<availlibrary>$$INDU$$LHESB$$1General Collection$$2(HQ 1665.15 .W65 2014 )$$Sunavailable$$31$$41$$5N$$60$$XNDU50$$YHESB$$ZGEN</availlibrary> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph004519265</lds02> 
<lds03>Breaks and continuities of two "great transformations" / Aino Saarinen, Kirsti Ekonen and Valentina Uspenskaia -- First-wave women's movement: result and factor of civil society formation in Russia / Irina Lukina -- The art of change: modernist women writers' feminist thinking / Kirsti Ekonen -- Integration or exploitation?: party political mobilization of women in early twentieth-century Russia / Vera Kulik -- Working for women's liberation in a radical fashion: family life in the emancipatory project of Aleksandra Kollontai / Valentina Uspenskaia -- Solving the "woman question": the case of zhenotdels in Tver province / Natalia Kozlova -- Perestroika and feminist critique / Elena Zdravomyslova -- Gender mainstreaming and the NGO-ization of Russian women's activism / Julie Hemment -- Russian public sphere from a gender perspective: the Arkhangelsk Region case / Natalia Kukarenko -- Karelian women's network: a women's movement? / Meri Kulmala -- Revisiting a transborder network project: combating gender violence in the Barents region / Aino Saarinen -- Sex trafficking, women's activism in Russia and the U.S. intervention / Janet Johnson.</lds03> 
<lds30>Routledge studies in the history of Russia and Eastern Europe ; ~~ 18.</lds30>

<creatorcontrib>edited by Aino Saarinen, Kirsti Ekonen and Valentina Uspenskaia.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Aino,  Saarinen  editor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Kirsti,  Ekonen  editor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>V. I.,  Uspenskai͡a  editor.</creatorcontrib>

<creatorcontrib>Uspenskai͡a  editor.</creatorcontrib> 
<title>Women and transformation in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> /</title> 
<description>This book looks at Russian women's mobilization and agency during the two periods of transformation, the turn of the 19th-20th century and the 20th - 21st century. Bringing together the parallels between the two great transformations, it focuses on both the continuities and breaks and, importantly, it shows them from the grassroots point of view, emphasizing the local factor. Chapters show the international and transnational aspects of Russian women's agency of different spheres and different historical periods. The book goes on to raise new research questions such as the evaluation and comparison of Soviet society and contemporary Russia from the point of view of gender and women's possibilities in society. --Amazon.com.</description> 
<subject>Feminism Russia (Federation).</subject> 
<general>Routledge, Taylor &amp; Francis Group,</general>

<toc>Breaks and continuities of two "great transformations" / Aino Saarinen, Kirsti Ekonen and Valentina Uspenskaia -- First-wave women's movement: result and factor of civil society formation in Russia / Irina Lukina -- The art of change: modernist women writers' feminist thinking / Kirsti Ekonen -- Integration or exploitation?: party political mobilization of women in early twentieth-century Russia / Vera Kulik -- Working for women's liberation in a radical fashion: family life in the emancipatory project of Aleksandra Kollontai / Valentina Uspenskaia -- Solving the "woman question": the case of zhenotdels in Tver province / Natalia Kozlova -- Perestroika and feminist critique / Elena Zdravomyslova -- Gender mainstreaming and the NGO-ization of Russian women's activism / Julie Hemment -- Russian public sphere from a gender perspective: the Arkhangelsk Region case / Natalia Kukarenko -- Karelian women's network: a women's movement? / Meri Kulmala -- Revisiting a transborder network project: combating gender violence in the Barents region / Aino Saarinen -- Sex trafficking, women's activism in Russia and the U.S. intervention / Janet Johnson.</toc>

<abstract>This book looks at Russian women's mobilization and agency during the two periods of transformation, the turn of the 19th-20th century and the 20th - 21st century. Bringing together the parallels between the two great transformations, it focuses on both the continuities and breaks and, importantly, it shows them from the grassroots point of view, emphasizing the local factor. Chapters show the international and transnational aspects of Russian women's agency of different spheres and different historical periods. The book goes on to raise new research questions such as the evaluation and comparison of Soviet society and contemporary Russia from the point of view of gender and women's possibilities in society. --Amazon.com.</abstract>

<title>$$DRussia, China and Eurasia$$ERussia, China and Eurasia</title>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Crises in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> contemporary management policy and practice from a historical perspective</title> 
<contributor>B. N Porfirʹev [Boris Nikolaevich]</contributor> 
<contributor>Greg Simons</contributor> 
<contributor>ebrary, Inc.</contributor> 
<publisher>Burlington, Vt. : Ashgate</publisher> 
<creationdate>2012</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource.</format> 
<subject>Public administration -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Crisis management -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<language>eng</language> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph003694450</lds02> 
<lds03>Crisis management and mass media in Russia: following the historical perspectives -- Institutional framework and governance model of the Russia crisis policy: disaster focus -- Managing alleviation of the 1995 Neftegorsk earthquake disaster -- Managing the ecological disaster in the town of Karabash -- Communicating tragedy and values through mass media during crises: the lessons of submarine accidents in Russia -- Social security policy for the Chernobyl clean-up and rescue workers: crisis chronology and lessons -- Institutional issues and the management of the creeping crisis in the Kabardina and Balkaria Republic of Russia -- Political and institutional factors of Russian banking crisis 2004 -- Vulnerability and crisis development: lessons from Russia and other emerging economies -- Conclusion: crisis management policy in transitional societies: beyond the Russia experience.</lds03>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Biological science and biotechnology in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> controlling diseases and enhancing security</title> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor> 
<contributor>National Research Council [U.S.]. Committee on Future Contributions of the Biosciences to Public Health, Agriculture, Basic Research, Counterterrorism, and Nonproliferation Activities in Russia.</contributor> 
<contributor>National Research Council [U.S.]. Office for Central Europe and Eurasia.</contributor> 
<contributor>National Research Council [U.S.]. Development, Security, and Cooperation.</contributor> 
<contributor>Rossiĭskai͡a akademii͡a nauk.</contributor> 
<contributor>Institute of Medicine [U.S.]</contributor> 
<publisher>Washington, D.C. : National Academies Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2006</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (x, 146 pages) : illustrations, portrait, charts.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V0309552052; $$CISBN $$V9780309552059</identifier> 
<subject>Biotechnology -- Research -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Bioterrorism -- Russia [Federation] -- Prevention</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>In July 2005, the National Academies released the report Biological Science and Biotechnology in Russia: Controlling Diseases and Enhancing Security. The report offered a number of recommendations that could help restore Russia s ability to join with the United States and the broader international community in leading an expanded global effort to control infectious diseases. A proposed bilateral intergovernmental commission could play a pivotal role toward that end as cooperation moves from assistance to partnership. The report proposed the establishment of two model State Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance Centers in Russia, more focused support of competitively selected Russian research groups as centers of excellence, the promotion of investments in biotechnology niches that are well suited for Russian companies, and expanded opportunities for young scientists to achieve scientific leadership positions in Russia. Also, the report highlighted the importance of U.S. programs that support the integration of former Soviet defense scientists with civilian researchers who had not been involved in military-related activities.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

Development, Security, and Cooperation</creatorcontrib><description>In July 2005, the National Academies released the report Biological Science and Biotechnology in Russia: Controlling Diseases and Enhancing Security. The report offered a number of recommendations that could help restore Russia s ability to join with the United States and the broader international community in leading an expanded global effort to control infectious diseases. A proposed bilateral intergovernmental commission could play a pivotal role toward that end as cooperation moves from assistance to partnership. The report proposed the establishment of two model State Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance Centers in Russia, more focused support of competitively selected Russian research groups as centers of excellence, the promotion of investments in biotechnology niches that are well suited for Russian companies, and expanded opportunities for young scientists to achieve scientific leadership positions in Russia. Also, the report highlighted the importance of U.S. programs that support the integration of former Soviet defense scientists with civilian researchers who had not been involved in military-related activities.</description><general>(OCoLC)65168508 (OCoLC)137342315 (OCoLC)326769427 (OCoLC)475333875 (OCoLC)647477024</general><general>OCoLC65168508 OCoLC137342315 OCoLC326769427 OCoLC475333875 OCoLC647477024</general><general>65168508 (OCoLC)137342315 (OCoLC)326769427 (OCoLC)475333875 (OCoLC)647477024</general><general>"In cooperation with Russian Academy of Sciences."</general><recordid>ndu_aleph003729131</recordid><recordid>003729131</recordid><recordid>3729131</recordid><isbn>0309552052</isbn><isbn>9780309552059</isbn><toc>A vision for Russia's future -- Pillar One: Improving surveillance and response -- Pillar Two: Meeting pathogen research challenges -- Pillar Three: The promise of biotechnology -- PIllar Four: The human resource base -- Reshaping U.S.-Russian cooperation in the biological sciences and biotechnology.</toc><addtitle>National Academies Press.</addtitle><addtitle>Biological science and biotechnology in Russia.</addtitle><lsr04>National Academies Press.</lsr04><creatorcontrib>Institute of Medicine</creatorcontrib><general>(OCoLC)65168508</general><general>OCoLC65168508</general><general>65168508</general><sourceid>smc_aleph</sourceid><recordid>smc_aleph000372444</recordid><recordid>000372444</recordid><recordid>372444</recordid><addtitle>ebrary</addtitle><addtitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</addtitle><searchscope>smc_aleph</searchscope><searchscope>SMC</searchscope><scope>smc_aleph</scope><scope>SMC</scope><scope>SMCebook</scope><lsr03>ebrary</lsr03><lsr03>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lsr03><lsr30>ebrary</lsr30><lsr30>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lsr30></search>

<addata><btitle>Biological science and biotechnology in Russia controlling diseases and enhancing security</btitle><risdate>c2006.</risdate><btitle>Biological science and biotechnology in Russia : controlling diseases and enhancing security</btitle><date>2006</date><risdate>2006.</risdate><isbn>0309097045</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references (p. 145-146).</notes><cop>Washington, D.C.</cop><pub>National Academies Press</pub><oclcid>64403451</oclcid><isbn>0309552052</isbn><isbn>9780309552059</isbn><notes>Includes bibliographical references.</notes><abstract>In July 2005, the National Academies released the report Biological Science and Biotechnology in Russia: Controlling Diseases and Enhancing Security. The report offered a number of recommendations that could help restore Russia s ability to join with the United States and the broader international community in leading an expanded global effort to control infectious diseases. A proposed bilateral intergovernmental commission could play a pivotal role toward that end as cooperation moves from assistance to partnership. The report proposed the establishment of two model State Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance Centers in Russia, more focused support of competitively selected Russian research groups as centers of excellence, the promotion of investments in biotechnology niches that are well suited for Russian companies, and expanded opportunities for young scientists to achieve scientific leadership positions in Russia. Also, the report highlighted the importance of U.S. programs that support the integration of former Soviet defense scientists with civilian researchers who had not been involved in military-related activities.</abstract><oclcid>65168508</oclcid><seriestitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</seriestitle></addata>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>Federalism and democratisation in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<creator>Cameron Ross 1951-</creator> 
<publisher>Manchester : Manchester University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2002</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9781781700174 (ebook)</identifier> 
<subject>Federal government -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Democratization -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<description>This book provides a comparative analysis of the electoral systems, party systems and governmental systems in the ethnic republics and regions of Russia and their impact on democratization and federalism, moving the focus of research from the national level to the vitally important processes of institution building and democratization at the local level and to the study of federalism in Russia.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph004400239</lds02> 
<version>2</version></display>

<creatorcontrib>Cameron,  Ross  1951-</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Ross, C</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Cameron Ross.</creatorcontrib> 
<title>Federalism and democratisation in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<description>This book provides a comparative analysis of the electoral systems, party systems and governmental systems in the ethnic republics and regions of Russia and their impact on democratization and federalism, moving the focus of research from the national level to the vitally important processes of institution building and democratization at the local level and to the study of federalism in Russia.</description>

<subject>Democratization Russia (Federation).</subject> 
<subject>Russia (Federation) Politics and government 1991-</subject>

<unititle>Russia pharmaceuticals &amp; healthcare report (Online)</unititle>

<title>The future of China-&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> relations</title>

<subject>China -- Relations -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Relations -- China</subject> 
<description>During the past decade China and Russia have made efforts to strengthen bilateral ties and improve cooperation on a number of diplomatic fronts. Scholars from around the world explore the current state of the relationship between two powers and assess the prospects for future cooperation and possible tensions in the new century.</description>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> in the Arctic</title> 
<contributor>Stephen Blank 1950-</contributor> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle, PA : Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</publisher> 
<creationdate>2011</creationdate> 
<format>viii, 141 p. : maps ; 23 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9781584874966; $$CISBN $$V1584874961</identifier> 
<subject>Russia [Federation]. Voenno-Morskoĭ Flot</subject> 
<subject>Jurisdiction, Territorial -- Arctic regions</subject> 
<subject>Power resources -- Arctic regions</subject> 
<subject>Natural resources -- Arctic regions</subject> 
<subject>Territorial waters -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Territorial waters -- United States</subject> 
<subject>Shipping -- Arctic regions</subject> 
<subject>National security -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>National security -- United States</subject> 
<subject>National strategy</subject> 
<subject>Arctic Coast [Russia] -- Strategic aspects</subject> 
<subject>Russia, Northern -- Strategic aspects</subject> 
<subject>Northwest Passage -- Strategic aspects</subject> 
<subject>Arctic regions -- Strategic aspects</subject> 
<subject>Arctic regions -- International status</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Armed Forces -- Arctic regions</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Military policy</subject> 
<description>The Arctic is the newest sphere of international competition for energy and security access. It pits Russia against the other Arctic states. These essays fully explore and analyze what is at stake here and what Moscow has done to increase its capability and influence in the Arctic.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VSSI monograph.</relation>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Historical legacies of Communism in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and Eastern Europe</title> 
<contributor>Mark R. Beissinger [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>Stephen Kotkin [editor]</contributor> 
<publisher>New York : Cambridge University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2014, ©2014</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (ix, 247 pages).</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9781107286191; $$CISBN $$V1107286190; $$CISBN $$V9781316009055; $$CISBN $$V131600905X; $$CISBN $$V9781316004555; $$CISBN $$V1316004554</identifier> 
<subject>Post-communism -- Economic aspects -- Europe, Eastern</subject> 
<subject>Post-communism -- Economic aspects -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Europe, Eastern -- Economic policy -- 1989-</subject> 
<description>"This book takes stock of arguments about the historical legacies of communism that have become common within the study of Russia and East Europe more than two decades after communism's demise and elaborates an empirical approach to the study of historical legacies revolving around relationships and mechanisms rather than correlation and outward similarities. Eleven essays by a distinguished group of scholars assess whether post-communist developments in specific areas continue to be shaped by the experience of communism or, alternatively, by fundamental divergences produced before or after communism. Chapters deal with the variable impact of the communist experience on post-communist societies in such areas as regime trajectories and democratic political values; patterns of regional and sectoral economic development; property ownership within the energy sector; the functioning of the executive branch of government, the police, and courts; the relationship of religion to the state; government language policies; and informal relationships and practices"-- Elaborates an empirical approach to the study of historical legacies of communism, revolving around relationships and mechanisms rather than correlation and outward similarities.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<rights>Access restricted to a single concurrent user.</rights> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph004126617</lds02> 
<lds03>1. The historical legacies of Communism: an empirical agenda ; Replacing transitions with legacies? ; What is a historical legacy? ; Forms of legacy relationships ; Toward more robust legacy arguments ; Organization of the volume -- 2. Communist development and the postcommunist democratic deficit ; Communist modernization- achievements and limitations ; Nondemocratizing development: assessing the regime legacies of Communism ; Explaining the unusual Communist development-democracy link ; Nondemocratizing education ; The secret charm of Communist cities? ; Conclusion and implications -- 3. Room for error: the economic legacy of Soviet spatial misallocation ; The legacy of spatial misallocation ; Origin of the legacy: how did it happen? ; Extent of the distortion ; The cost of the distortion ; Is the legacy being overcome? ; Conclusion: dealing with the "gnarled tree economy" -- 4. Legacies of industrialization and paths of transnational integration after Socialism ; Inherited socialist and emerging capitalist industries: continuity and change ; Logics of foreign-led reindustrialization and deindustrialization ; Perceptions and choices in uncertain conditions ; Conclusions -- 5. The limits of legacies: property rights in Russian energy ; Common legacy, different outcomes: the privatization of oil and gas ; One legacy, different outcomes over time: expropriation in the oil sector ; Different legacies, similar outcomes? ; Conclusion -- 6. Legacies and departures in the Russian state executive ; Legacy patterns in the organization of the postcommunist Russian executive ; Legacy patterns in the recruitment of the postcommunist Russian executive ; Legacy patterns in the rituals of the postcommunist Russian executive ; Conclusion -- 7. From police state to police state? Legacies and law enforcement in Russia ; What counts as a legacy? ; Organizational legacies in Russian law enforcement ; FSB ; MVD ; The procuracy ; Organizational legacies: summary ; Cultural and behavioral legacies ; Policing and personal freedom ; Institutional rivalry and elite Chekists ; Everyday policing: serving the plan and one's pocket ; Cultural and behavioral legacies: summary ; Conclusion -- 8. How judges arrest and acquit ; Wholesale approval of pretrial detention ; Legacy as fragmentation ; Legacy as translation ; Legacy as bricolage ; Avoidance of acquittals in postcommunist criminal justice ; Legacy as fragmentation ; Legacy as translation ; Legacy as bricolage ; Conclusion -- 9. Historical roots of religious influence on postcommunist democratic politics ; Differences in policy influence across postcommunist democracy ; Communist legacies, religion, and national identities.</lds03>

<title>Historical legacies of Communism in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and Eastern Europe /</title> 
<description>"This book takes stock of arguments about the historical legacies of communism that have become common within the study of Russia and East Europe more than two decades after communism's demise and elaborates an empirical approach to the study of historical legacies revolving around relationships and mechanisms rather than correlation and outward similarities. Eleven essays by a distinguished group of scholars assess whether post-communist developments in specific areas continue to be shaped by the experience of communism or, alternatively, by fundamental divergences produced before or after communism. Chapters deal with the variable impact of the communist experience on post-communist societies in such areas as regime trajectories and democratic political values; patterns of regional and sectoral economic development; property ownership within the energy sector; the functioning of the executive branch of government, the police, and courts; the relationship of religion to the state; government language policies; and informal relationships and practices"-- Provided by publisher.</description> 
<description>Elaborates an empirical approach to the study of historical legacies of communism, revolving around relationships and mechanisms rather than correlation and outward similarities.</description>

<abstract>"This book takes stock of arguments about the historical legacies of communism that have become common within the study of Russia and East Europe more than two decades after communism's demise and elaborates an empirical approach to the study of historical legacies revolving around relationships and mechanisms rather than correlation and outward similarities. Eleven essays by a distinguished group of scholars assess whether post-communist developments in specific areas continue to be shaped by the experience of communism or, alternatively, by fundamental divergences produced before or after communism. Chapters deal with the variable impact of the communist experience on post-communist societies in such areas as regime trajectories and democratic political values; patterns of regional and sectoral economic development; property ownership within the energy sector; the functioning of the executive branch of government, the police, and courts; the relationship of religion to the state; government language policies; and informal relationships and practices"--</abstract> 
<abstract>Elaborates an empirical approach to the study of historical legacies of communism, revolving around relationships and mechanisms rather than correlation and outward similarities.</abstract>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Putin's &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>.</title> 
<creator>Lilia. Shevtsova</creator> 
<contributor>JSTOR [Organization].</contributor> 
<edition>2nd ed..</edition> 
<publisher>Washington DC : Carnegie Endowment for International Peace</publisher> 
<creationdate>2010</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (475 pages).</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780870032936 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V0870032933 (electronic bk.) (discovery)</identifier> 
<subject>Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich, 1952-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<description>This revised edition includes and examination of the recent presidential and parliamentary elections and their effects on Putin's leadership and Russia. Praise for the previous edition:""Out of her blunt, often acerbic, account come shrewd insights into Putin's transformation from an implausible, contrived successor into a dominator unchallenged by oligarchs, legislators, or regional bosses, let alone a democratic opposition.""--Foreign Affairs""Shevtsova is one of the most astute and independent-minded observers of the Russian political scene.""-Times Literary Supplement""Offers many insight.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

Russia Tranquilized; Chapter 7. The Long-Awaited Breakthrough; Chapter 8. The Kremlin's Ambiguity; Chapter 9. Russia Goes Through New Elections; Chapter 10. Russia Has a New President -- Again Putin; Chapter 11. From Oligarchic Authoritarianism to Bureaucratic Authoritarianism; Chapter 12. New Agenda and New Disappointments.</lds03><version>2</version></display>

Praise for the previous edition:""Out of her blunt, often acerbic, account come shrewd insights into Putin's transformation from an implausible, contrived successor into a dominator unchallenged by oligarchs, legislators, or regional bosses, let alone a democratic opposition.""--Foreign Affairs""Shevtsova is one of the most astute and independent-minded observers of the Russian political scene.""-Times Literary Supplement""Offers many insight.</abstract><cop>Washington DC</cop><pub>Carnegie Endowment for International Peace</pub><oclcid>830169679</oclcid><aulast>Shevt͡sova</aulast><aufirst>Lilii͡a,</aufirst><au>Shevt͡sova, Lilii͡a</au></addata>
<browse>

<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> : a long view</title> 
<creator>E. T. Gaĭdar [Egor Timurovich]</creator> 
<contributor>Antonina W Bouis</contributor> 
<contributor>JSTOR [Organization].</contributor> 
<publisher>Cambridge, Mass. : MIT Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2012</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xviii, 543 pages) : illustrations.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V0262305305 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V9780262305303 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V9780262306225 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V0262306220 (electronic bk.) (discovery)</identifier>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Land reform in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> : institutional design and behavioral responses</title> 
<creator>Stephen K. Wegren 1956-</creator> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor> 
<publisher>New Haven : Yale University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>©2009</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xix, 340 pages)..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780300156409; $$CISBN $$V0300156405; $$CISBN $$V0300150970; $$CISBN $$V9780300150971</identifier> 
<subject>Land reform -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Right of property -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Rural development -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>This work is the definitive account of Russia's land reform initiatives from the late 1980s to today. In Russia, a country controlling more land than any other nation, land ownership is central to structures of power, class division, and agricultural production.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VYale agrarian studies.</relation>

<addata><btitle>Land reform in Russia : institutional design and behavioral responses</btitle><risdate>©2009.</risdate><isbn>9780300156409</isbn><isbn>0300156405</isbn><isbn>0300150970</isbn><abstract>This work is the definitive account of Russia's land reform initiatives from the late 1980s to today. In Russia, a country controlling more land than any other nation, land ownership is central to structures of power, class division, and agricultural production.</abstract><aulast>Wegren</aulast><aufirst>Stephen K.,</aufirst><au>Wegren, Stephen K.</au><btitle>Land reform in Russia institutional design and behavioral responses</btitle><seriestitle>Yale agrarian studies</seriestitle><date>2009</date><risdate>c2009.</risdate><isbn>9780300150971</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><cop>New Haven</cop><pub>Yale University Press</pub><seriestitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</seriestitle><oclcid>593257187</oclcid></addata>

<type>video</type> 
<title>Discovering &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<contributor>Masha Nordbye 1955-</contributor> 
<contributor>International Video Network.</contributor> 
<publisher>San Ramon, CA : International Video Network</publisher> 
<creationdate>c1995</creationdate> 
<format>1 videocassette (60 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1563452847</identifier> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Description and travel</subject> 
<description>Presents a tour of historical, cultural, scenic, and industrial sites of Russia.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

<sourcerecordid>$$V000349804$$Obci_aleph000349804</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V003516768$$Ondu_aleph003516768</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V001949826$$Ondu_aleph001949826</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V000272344$$Osmc_aleph000272344</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vbci_aleph$$Obci_aleph000349804</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003516768</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph001949826</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vsmc_aleph$$Osmc_aleph000272344</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg100848380</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VBCI01$$Obci_aleph000349804</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003516768</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph001949826</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VSMC01$$Osmc_aleph000272344</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Obci_aleph000349804</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003516768</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph001949826</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Osmc_aleph000272344</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Obci_aleph000349804</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003516768</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph001949826</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Osmc_aleph000272344</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VBCI01000349804$$Obci_aleph000349804</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003516768$$Ondu_aleph003516768</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01001949826$$Ondu_aleph001949826</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VSMC01000272344$$Osmc_aleph000272344</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>All &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> is burning! : a cultural history of fire and arson in late Imperial &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<creator>Cathy A. Frierson</creator> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor> 
<publisher>Seattle : University of Washington Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>©2002</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (x, 318 pages) : illustrations.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780295801469; $$CISBN $$V0295801468</identifier> 
<subject>Arson -- Russia -- History -- 19th century</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Social life and customs</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>"Rural fires were an even more persistent scourge than famine in late imperial Russia, as Cathy Frierson shows in this first comprehensive study. Destroying almost 3 billion rubles' worth of property in European Russia between 1860 and 1904, accidental and arson fires acted as a brake on Russia's economic development while subjecting peasants to perennial shocks to their physical and emotional condition. The fire question especially captured the attention of educated, progressive Russians, who perceived it as a key obstacle to Russia's becoming a modern society on the European model." "More than anything else, this history of fire and arson in rural European Russia is a history of their cultural meanings in the late imperial campaign for modernity. Frierson shows the special associations of women with fire in rural life and in elite understanding of fire in the Russian countryside. Her study of the fire question demonstrates both peasant agency in fighting fire and educated Russians' hardening conviction that peasants stood in the way of Russia's advent into the company of prosperous, rational, civilized nations."--Jacket.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
 
 
 
<availlibrary>$$INDU$$LHESB$$1General Collection$$2(HV 6638.5 .R8 F75 2002 )$$Savailable$$31$$40$$5N$$61$$XNDU50$$YHESB$$ZGEN$$Ondu_aleph001949826</availlibrary><availinstitution>$$INDU$$Savailable</availinstitution><availpnx>available</availpnx><lds01>"A Samuel and Althea Stroum book."</lds01><lds01>"A Samuel &amp; Althea Stroum book."</lds01><lds02>bci_aleph000349804</lds02><lds02>ndu_aleph003516768</lds02><lds02>ndu_aleph001949826</lds02><lds02>smc_aleph000272344</lds02><lds03>From Benevolent Force to National Misfortune: Fire's Contested Meanings in Rural Russia -- Fire as Gentle Cookery and Paradise: Peasants as Mistresses and Masters of Fire -- Fire as Apocalypse or Pathology: Peasants as Victims or Vectors of Fire -- Fire as Russia's Historical Evil: Peasants Dispossessed by Fire -- Letting Loose the Red Rooster: Arson in Rural Russia -- The Fiery Brand, Russian Style: Arson as Protest, Peasants as Incendiaries -- Arson as Impotent Spite or Potent Practice: Peasants as Vengeful, Covetous, or Wily Actors -- Mobilizing to Make Russia Modern: Insuring, Planning, Volunteering -- Fire as Insurance Hazard: Peasants as Students of Prudence and Precaution -- Fire Contained in the Planned Village: Peasants as Residents in a Disciplined Domestic Order -- Fire as the Internal Enemy: Peasants as Volunteer Firefighters -- Conclusion: Fire as an Imperial Legacy, Peasants as Partners in Progress -- Total reported fires by province, 1863 -- Total reported fires by province, 1873 -- Total reported fires by province, 1883 -- Total reported fires by province, 1893 -- Population density in 1897 -- Fires per population in 1897 -- Percentage of reported fires attributed to arson, 1860s -- Percentage of reported fires attributed to arson, 1870s -- Percentage of reported fires attributed to arson, 1880s -- Percentage of reported fires attributed to arson, 1890s -- Percentage of reported fires attributed to arson, 1900-1904 -- Provinces where percentage of fires attributed to arson increased, 1888-1904.</lds03><lds30>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lds30><snippetfield>title</snippetfield><snippetfield>title</snippetfield><snippet><![CDATA[All <span class="searchword">Russia</span> is burning! a cultural history of fire and arson in late Imperial <span class="searchword">Russia</span> /...
