<addata><risdate>©2002.</risdate><isbn>0295801468</isbn><abstract>"Rural fires were an even more persistent scourge than famine in late imperial Russia, as Cathy Frierson shows in this first comprehensive study. Destroying almost 3 billion rubles' worth of property in European Russia between 1860 and 1904, accidental and arson fires acted as a brake on Russia's economic development while subjecting peasants to perennial shocks to their physical and emotional condition. The fire question especially captured the attention of educated, progressive Russians, who perceived it as a key obstacle to Russia's becoming a modern society on the European model."</abstract><abstract>"More than anything else, this history of fire and arson in rural European Russia is a history of their cultural meanings in the late imperial campaign for modernity. Frierson shows the special associations of women with fire in rural life and in elite understanding of fire in the Russian countryside. Her study of the fire question demonstrates both peasant agency in fighting fire and educated Russians' hardening conviction that peasants stood in the way of Russia's advent into the company of prosperous, rational, civilized nations."--Jacket.</abstract><oclcid>808377046</oclcid><aulast>Frierson</aulast><aufirst>Cathy A.</aufirst><au>Frierson, Cathy A</au><btitle>All Russia is burning! a cultural history of fire and arson in late Imperial Russia</btitle><date>2002</date><risdate>c2002.</risdate><isbn>029598208X</isbn><isbn>0295982098</isbn><isbn>9780295801469</isbn><isbn>9780295982090</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><cop>Seattle</cop><pub>University of Washington Press</pub><btitle>All Russia is burning! : a cultural history of fire and arson in late Imperial Russia</btitle><notes>Includes bibliographical references (p. 298-312) and index.</notes><oclcid>48475296</oclcid><lccn>2001057005</lccn><seriestitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</seriestitle></addata>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Orthodox Christianity in Imperial &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> A Source Book on Lived Religion.</title> 
<contributor>Heather J. Coleman 1968-</contributor> 
<publisher>Bloomington, IN : Indiana University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2014</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (348 p.).</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780253013187; $$CISBN $$V0253013186</identifier> 
<subject>Russkai︠a︡ pravoslavnai︠a︡ t︠s︡erkovʹ -- Russia</subject> 
<subject>Christianity -- Russia</subject> 
<subject>Church history -- Sources</subject> 
<subject>Christian life -- Russia</subject> 
<subject>Spiritual life -- Russkai͡a pravoslavnai͡a t͡serkovʹ</subject> 
<subject>Sermons, Russian</subject> 
<subject>Miracles -- Russia</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>From sermons and clerical reports to personal stories of faith, this book of translated primary documents reveals the lived experience of Orthodox Christianity in 19th- and early 20th-century Russia. These documents allow us to hear the voices of educated and uneducated writers, of clergy and laity, nobles and merchants, workers and peasants, men and women, Russians and Ukrainians. Orthodoxy emerges here as a multidimensional and dynamic faith. Beyond enhancing our understanding of Orthodox Christianity as practiced in Imperial Russia, this thoughtfully edited volume offers broad insights into.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VEBSCOhost eBook collection</relation>

<addata><btitle>Orthodox Christianity in Imperial Russia A Source Book on Lived Religion.</btitle><seriestitle>EBSCOhost eBook collection</seriestitle><abstract>From sermons and clerical reports to personal stories of faith, this book of translated primary documents reveals the lived experience of Orthodox Christianity in 19th- and early 20th-century Russia. These documents allow us to hear the voices of educated and uneducated writers, of clergy and laity, nobles and merchants, workers and peasants, men and women, Russians and Ukrainians. Orthodoxy emerges here as a multidimensional and dynamic faith. Beyond enhancing our understanding of Orthodox Christianity as practiced in Imperial Russia, this thoughtfully edited volume offers broad insights into.</abstract><aulast>Coleman</aulast><aufirst>Heather J.,</aufirst><addau>Coleman, Heather J.</addau><btitle>Orthodox Christianity in Imperial Russia : a Source Book on Lived Religion.</btitle><date>2014</date><risdate>2014.</risdate><isbn>9780253013187</isbn><isbn>0253013186</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references (pages 315-317) and index.</notes><cop>Bloomington, IN</cop><pub>Indiana University Press</pub><oclcid>894171682</oclcid><btitle>Orthodox Christianity in imperial Russia : a source book on lived religion</btitle><isbn>9780253013132</isbn><isbn>0253013135</isbn><isbn>9780253013170</isbn><isbn>0253013178</isbn><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><oclcid>857403596</oclcid><lccn>2014001386</lccn><btitle>Orthodox Christianity in imperial Russia a source book on lived religion</btitle><risdate>[2014]</risdate><cop>Bloomington</cop></addata>

<publisher>United Kingdom : ARC Music</publisher> 
<creationdate>2009</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (1 sound file)..</format>

<subject>Balalaika music</subject> 
<language>rus</language> 
<lds01>Ensemble Wolga.</lds01> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph003836849</lds02> 
<lds03>A solider on the banks of the Volga (3:00) -- Rucheyok (3:41) -- Svetit myesiats (3:57) -- Podmoskvniye vyechera (4:35) -- Yablochki (3:29) -- Sasha, play for the dance (3:36) -- Dance kazachok (3:42) -- Wedding in St. Petersburg (3:28) -- The mail coach (4:58) -- Fom Kaluka to Tula (3:07) -- Ey ras poshol (3:28) -- Ekh dorogi (3:09).</lds03> 
<lds05>Sung in Russian.</lds05>

<type>book</type> 
<title>Digital &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> : the language, culture and politics of new media communication</title> 
<contributor>Michael Gorham [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>Ingunn Lunde 1969- [editor]</contributor> 
<contributor>Martin Paulsen [editor]</contributor> 
<publisher>London ; New York : Routledge/Taylor &amp; Francis Group</publisher> 
<creationdate>2014</creationdate> 
<format>xvi, 292 pages : illustrations ; 24 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780415707046; $$CISBN $$V0415707048; $$CISBN $$V1317810740; $$CISBN $$V9781317810742</identifier> 
<subject>Internet -- Social aspects -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Information technology -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russian language</subject> 
<description>"This book provides a comprehensive analysis of the ways in which new media technologies have shaped language and communication in contemporary Russia. It traces the development of the Russian language internet, explores the evolution of web-based communication practices showing how they have shaped and reshaped social, political, linguistic and literary reality, and examines online features and trends which are characteristic of, and in some cases specific to, the Russian language internet"--</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VRoutledge contemporary Russia and Eastern Europe series ; 53.</relation>

<title>Digital &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> : the language, culture and politics of new media communication /</title> 
<description>"This book provides a comprehensive analysis of the ways in which new media technologies have shaped language and communication in contemporary Russia. It traces the development of the Russian language internet, explores the evolution of web-based communication practices showing how they have shaped and reshaped social, political, linguistic and literary reality, and examines online features and trends which are characteristic of, and in some cases specific to, the Russian language internet"-- Provided by publisher.</description>

<title>Imperial &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> new histories for the Empire</title> 
<contributor>Jane Burbank</contributor> 
<contributor>David L Ransel</contributor> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor> 
<publisher>Bloomington : Indiana University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>©1998</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xxiii, 359 pages) : illustrations..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V0253108500; $$CISBN $$V9780253108500</identifier> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- History -- 18th century</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- History -- 19th century</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>"On the basis of the work presented here, one can say that the future of American scholarship on imperial Russia is in good hands."--American Historial Review" ... innovative and substantive research ..."--The Russian Review"Anyone wishing to understand the 'state of the field' in Imperial Russian history would do well to start with this collection." -- Theodore W. Weeks, H-Net Reviews"The essays are impressive in terms of research conceptualization, and analysis." -- Slavic ReviewPresen.</description>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the North</title> 
<contributor>Elana Wilson Rowe 1980-</contributor> 
<contributor>JSTOR [Organization].</contributor> 
<publisher>Ottawa : University of Ottawa Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>©2009</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xi, 218 pages) : illustrations, maps.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780776618029 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V0776618024 (electronic bk.) (discovery)</identifier> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia, Northern -- Social conditions</subject> 
<subject>Russia, Northern -- Environmental conditions</subject> 
<subject>Russia, Northern -- Economic conditions</subject> 
<subject>Russia, Northern -- Politics and government</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Foreign relations</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Military policy</subject> 
<description>"Russia holds more Arctic territory than any other state, yet unlike other Arctic states it does not have a unified strategy identifying economic and political aims for the North. Russia's policies on the North are dispersed across a variety of fields from domestic migration politics to oil and gas development. This volume engages the disparate elements of Russian northern policy and illustrates how the centralized, relatively economically strong and politically assertive Russia of today defines and addresses northern spaces, opportunities, and challenges. As energy markets continue looking northward and climate change renders the Arctic increasingly accessible, the geopolitical interests of Arctic states will be brought more frequently to the forefront. These circumstances will make the disputed borders and overlapping sovereignty claims of the North an important topic in international politics. Given its geographic size and political influence, Russia is and will continue to be a key regional and global actor in the international politics of the North"--Provided by publisher.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

Baev -- Cross-border cooperation in the North : the case of Northwest Russia / Geir Hønneland -- Climate change in the Russian North : threats real and potential / Craig ZumBrunnen -- Recent developments inn the Russian fisheries sector / Anne-Kristin Jørgensen -- Northern offshore oil and gas resources : policy challenges and approaches / Arild Moe and Elana Wilson Rowe -- Growth poles and ghost towns in the Russian Far North / Timothy Heleniak -- Indigenous rights in the Russian North / Indra Øverland -- Oil and gas development in Russia and Northern Indigenous Peoples / Anna A. Sirina -- The intersection of Northern and national policies / Elana Wilson Rowe.</lds03><lds30>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lds30></display>

<search><creatorcontrib>edited by Elana Wilson Rowe.</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Elana Wilson Rowe -- Pavel K. Baev -- Geir Hønneland -- Craig ZumBrunnen -- Anne-Kristin Jørgensen -- Arild Moe and Elana Wilson Rowe -- Timothy Heleniak -- Indra Øverland -- Anna A. Sirina -- Elana Wilson Rowe.</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Elana,  Wilson Rowe  1980-</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Wilson Rowe, E</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>JSTOR (Organization).</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Rowe, Elana Wilson, 1980-</creatorcontrib><title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the North /</title><description>"Russia holds more Arctic territory than any other state, yet unlike other Arctic states it does not have a unified strategy identifying economic and political aims for the North. Russia's policies on the North are dispersed across a variety of fields from domestic migration politics to oil and gas development. This volume engages the disparate elements of Russian northern policy and illustrates how the centralized, relatively economically strong and politically assertive Russia of today defines and addresses northern spaces, opportunities, and challenges. As energy markets continue looking northward and climate change renders the Arctic increasingly accessible, the geopolitical interests of Arctic states will be brought more frequently to the forefront. These circumstances will make the disputed borders and overlapping sovereignty claims of the North an important topic in international politics. Given its geographic size and political influence, Russia is and will continue to be a key regional and global actor in the international politics of the North"--Provided by publisher.</description><subject>Russia (Federation) Politics and government 1991-</subject><subject>Russia, Northern Social conditions.</subject><subject>Russia, Northern Environmental conditions.</subject><subject>Russia, Northern Economic conditions.</subject><subject>Russia, Northern Politics and government.</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Foreign relations.</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Military policy.</subject><subject>Russia (Federation) Foreign relations 1991-</subject><general>University of Ottawa Press,</general><general>10.2307/j.ctt1ckpdbd</general><general>JSTOR Books at JSTOR Demand Driven Acquisitions</general><general>(OCoLC)500984394 (OCoLC)646830213 (OCoLC)753295670 (OCoLC)781337143 (OCoLC)870408348</general><general>OCoLC500984394 OCoLC646830213 OCoLC753295670 OCoLC781337143 OCoLC870408348</general><general>500984394 (OCoLC)646830213 (OCoLC)753295670 (OCoLC)781337143 (OCoLC)870408348</general><general>AllDocuments</general><sourceid>ndu_aleph</sourceid><recordid>ndu_aleph004465136</recordid><recordid>004465136</recordid><recordid>4465136</recordid><isbn>9780776618029</isbn><isbn>0776618024</isbn><isbn>9780776607009</isbn><isbn>0776607006</isbn><toc>Policy aims and political realities in the Russian North / Elana Wilson Rowe -- Troublemaking and risk-taking : the North in Russian military activities / Pavel K. Baev -- Cross-border cooperation in the North : the case of Northwest Russia / Geir Hønneland -- Climate change in the Russian North : threats real and potential / Craig ZumBrunnen -- Recent developments inn the Russian fisheries sector / Anne-Kristin Jørgensen -- Northern offshore oil and gas resources : policy challenges and approaches / Arild Moe and Elana Wilson Rowe -- Growth poles and ghost towns in the Russian Far North / Timothy Heleniak -- Indigenous rights in the Russian North / Indra Øverland -- Oil and gas development in Russia and Northern Indigenous Peoples / Anna A. Sirina -- The intersection of Northern and national policies / Elana Wilson Rowe.</toc><creationdate>2009</creationdate><startdate>20090101</startdate><addtitle>Russia and the North.</addtitle><enddate>20091231</enddate><searchscope>ndu_aleph</searchscope><searchscope>NDU</searchscope><scope>ndu_aleph</scope><scope>NDU</scope><scope>NDUebook</scope><lsr02>Wilson Rowe Russia and the North</lsr02><lsr02>Russia and the North Wilson Rowe</lsr02><lsr07>Wilson Rowe Russia and the North</lsr07><lsr07>Russia and the North Wilson Rowe</lsr07><lsr06>University of Ottawa Press,</lsr06><lsr08>Ottawa :</lsr08><creatorcontrib>ebrary, Inc.</creatorcontrib><title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and the North</title><subject>Geopolitics Russia (Federation)</subject><subject>Electronic books.</subject><general>[electronic resource] /</general><general>(OCoLC)500984394</general><general>OCoLC500984394</general><general>500984394</general><sourceid>smc_aleph</sourceid><recordid>smc_aleph000324413</recordid><recordid>000324413</recordid><recordid>324413</recordid><addtitle>ebrary</addtitle><addtitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</addtitle><searchscope>smc_aleph</searchscope><searchscope>SMC</searchscope><scope>smc_aleph</scope><scope>SMC</scope><scope>SMCebook</scope><lsr03>ebrary</lsr03><lsr03>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lsr03><lsr30>ebrary</lsr30><lsr30>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lsr30><subject>Geopolitics Russia (Federation).</subject><general>(CaPaEBR)ebr10330229</general><general>CaPaEBRebr10330229</general><general>ebr10330229</general><recordid>ndu_aleph003040729</recordid><recordid>003040729</recordid><recordid>3040729</recordid><addtitle>Academic complete.</addtitle><lsr04>Academic complete.</lsr04></search>

<delivery><institution>$$VNDU$$Ondu_aleph004465136</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ondu_aleph004465136</delcategory><institution>$$VSMC$$Osmc_aleph000324413</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Osmc_aleph000324413</delcategory><institution>$$VNDU$$Ondu_aleph003040729</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ondu_aleph003040729</delcategory></delivery>

<addata><aulast>Wilson Rowe</aulast><aufirst>Elana,</aufirst><addau>Wilson Rowe, Elana</addau><btitle>Russia and the North</btitle><date>2009</date><risdate>©2009.</risdate><isbn>9780776618029</isbn><isbn>0776618024</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><abstract>"Russia holds more Arctic territory than any other state, yet unlike other Arctic states it does not have a unified strategy identifying economic and political aims for the North. Russia's policies on the North are dispersed across a variety of fields from domestic migration politics to oil and gas development. This volume engages the disparate elements of Russian northern policy and illustrates how the centralized, relatively economically strong and politically assertive Russia of today defines and addresses northern spaces, opportunities, and challenges. As energy markets continue looking northward and climate change renders the Arctic increasingly accessible, the geopolitical interests of Arctic states will be brought more frequently to the forefront. These circumstances will make the disputed borders and overlapping sovereignty claims of the North an important topic in international politics. Given its geographic size and political influence, Russia is and will continue to be a key regional and global actor in the international politics of the North"--Provided by publisher.</abstract><cop>Ottawa</cop><pub>University of Ottawa Press</pub><oclcid>500984394</oclcid><seriestitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</seriestitle><risdate>c2009.</risdate><isbn>0776607006</isbn><isbn>9780776607009</isbn></addata>

<subject>Finance -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Economic conditions -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Economic policy -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>Russia Rebounds analyzes Russia's dramatic economic recovery since the country's 1998 financial crisis, emphasizing macroeconomic issues and fiscal and banking sector reforms. The crisis was a massive shock to the system and a considerable surprise to both Russians and foreign investors, who a year before had come to think that the worst of the transition from a centrally planned to a market economy was over. Macroeconomic performance since the crisis has been impressive. The book assesses the contribution of various factors underlying this recovery and highlights key policy challenges to ensure its sustainability.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

Robinson -- Structural reforms and the growth outlook / Timo Välilä -- Tax reform in Russia / Dale Chua -- Public expenditure reform / David O. Robinson -- Banking crisis and recovery / David O. Robinson -- Debt crisis in Russia : the road from default to sustainability / Alejandro Santos.</lds03><lds30>Academic Complete (ebrary)</lds30></display>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>Implementing international environmental agreements in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<creator>Geir. Hønneland</creator> 
<contributor>Anne-Kristin Jørgensen</contributor> 
<publisher>Manchester : Manchester University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2003</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9781781700181 (ebook)</identifier> 
<subject>Environmental law, International</subject> 
<subject>International law -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<description>This systematic study considers how international environmental agreements are transformed into political action in Russia, using three illuminating case studies on the implementation process in the fields of fisheries management, nuclear safety and air pollution control. It develops the social science debate on international environmental regimes and "implementing activities" at both national and international level to include regional considerations.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph004400253</lds02> 
<version>2</version></display>

<title>Implementing international environmental agreements in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<description>This systematic study considers how international environmental agreements are transformed into political action in Russia, using three illuminating case studies on the implementation process in the fields of fisheries management, nuclear safety and air pollution control. It develops the social science debate on international environmental regimes and "implementing activities" at both national and international level to include regional considerations.</description>

<title>The history of the life of Peter the First, Emperor of &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>. Containing, a description of &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> or Muscovy, Siberia, Crim Tartary, &amp;c. With an account of the government, religion, ceremonies and superstitions, customs, Manners and Dress of the Inhabitants. Also, the birth and rise of the Empress Catharine, with the Crimes and Trial of the Czarewitz, Son of Peter I</title>

<title>The history of the life of Peter the First, Emperor of &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>. Containing, a description of &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> or Muscovy, Siberia, Crim Tartary, &amp;c. With an account of the government, religion, ceremonies and superstitions, customs, Manners and Dress of the Inhabitants. Also, the birth and rise of the Empress Catharine, with the Crimes and Trial of the Czarewitz, Son of Peter I</title> 
<subject>Peter I, Emperor of Russia, 1672-1725.</subject> 
<subject>Russia History Peter I, 1689-1725.</subject> 
<subject>Pierre I, Emperor of Russia, 1672-1725</subject> 
<subject>Peter, de Grote, 1672-1725</subject> 
<subject>Petr I Alekseevich, Emperor of Russia, 1672-1725</subject>

<title>Edible plants used by Siberian Yupik Eskimos of southeastern Chukotka Peninsula, &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span></title> 
<creator>L. I. Aĭnana [Li͡udmila Ivanovna],</creator>

<contributor>Richard L. Bland [translator]</contributor>

<creationdate>2014</creationdate>

<creatorcontrib>Aĭnana, Lauthor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Lyudmila Ainana and Igor Zagrebin ; English translation by Richard L. Bland.</creatorcontrib>

<title>Edible plants used by Siberian Yupik Eskimos of southeastern Chukotka Peninsula, &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> /</title>

bnail>http://books.google.com/books?bibkeys=ISBN:,OCLC:5107831,LCCN:08034984&amp;jscmd=viewapi&amp;callback=updateGBSCover</sear:thumbnail><sear:thumbnail>http://books.google.com/books?bibkeys=ISBN:,OCLC:5107831,LCCN:08034984&amp;jscmd=viewapi&amp;callback=updateGBSCover</sear:thumbnail><sear:openurlfulltext><![CDATA[http://findtext.library.nd.edu:8889/ndu_local?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&ctx_tim=2017-04-01T12%3A05%3A54IST&url_ver=Z39.88-2004&url_ctx_fmt=infofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rfr_id=info:sid/primo.exlibrisgroup.com:primo3-Journal-hathi_pub&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:book&rft.genre=&rft.atitle=&rft.jtitle=&rft.btitle=Russia%20under%20the%20tzars.&rft.aulast=Stepniak&rft.auinit=&rft.auinit1=&rft.auinitm=&rft.ausuffix=&rft.au=Stepniak,%20S.&rft.aucorp=&rft.volume=&rft.issue=&rft.part=&rft.quarter=&rft.ssn=&rft.spage=&rft.epage=&rft.pages=&rft.artnum=&rft.issn=&rft.eissn=&rft.isbn=&rft.sici=&rft.coden=&rft_id=info:doi/&rft.object_id=&svc_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:sch_svc&svc.fulltext=yes&rft.eisbn=&rft_dat=<hathi_pub>MIU01-006074546</hathi_pub><grp_id>73627015</grp_id><oa></oa>&rft_id=info:oai/&req.language=]]></sear:openurlfulltext><sear:linktoholdings>OVP</sear:linktoholdings><sear:linktouc>http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=no%3A5107831</sear:linktouc><sear:lln01/></sear:LINKS></sear:DOC><sear:DOC ID="6216444" RANK="7.153717E-4" NO="180" SEARCH_ENGINE="Local Search Engine" SEARCH_ENGINE_TYPE="Local Search Engine"><PrimoNMBib xmlns="http://www.exlibrisgroup.com/xsd/primo/primo_nm_bib">
<record>
<control>
<sourcerecordid>003890367</sourcerecordid> 
<sourceid>ndu_aleph</sourceid> 
<recordid>ndu_aleph003890367</recordid> 
<originalsourceid>NDU01</originalsourceid> 
<ilsapiid>NDU01003890367</ilsapiid> 
<sourceformat>MARC21</sourceformat> 
<sourcesystem>Aleph</sourcesystem> 
</control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia's&lt;/span> postcolonial identity : a subaltern empire in a Eurocentric world</title> 
<creator>Viatcheslav Morozov</creator> 
<publisher>Houndmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire : Palgrave Macmillan</publisher> 
<creationdate>2015</creationdate> 
<format>viii, 209 pages ; 23 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9781137409294; $$CISBN $$V1137409290</identifier> 
<subject>Postcolonialism -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Identity politics -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Imperialism</subject> 
<subject>Eurocentrism -- Political aspects -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Globalization -- Political aspects -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Political culture -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Foreign relations</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Politics and government -- 1991-</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Relations -- Western countries</subject> 
<subject>Western countries -- Relations -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<description>"This book applies postcolonial theory to Russia by looking at it as a subaltern empire. It pushes postcolonial studies and constructivist international relations towards an uneasy dialogue, which produces tensions and reveals multiple blind spots in both approaches. A critical re-evaluation of the existing literature enables the author to produce a comprehensive account of how Russia's position in the international system has conditioned its domestic development, and how this in turn generated specific foreign policy outcomes. Having internalised the Eurocentric worldview, Russia is nevertheless different from the core European countries. This difference is not determined by 'culture', but rather by uneven and combined development of global capitalism, in which Russia is integrated as a semi-peripheral nation. The Russian state has colonised its own periphery on behalf of the Western core, but has never been able to overcome economic and normative dependency on the West. The peculiar dialectic of the subaltern and the imperial during the post-Soviet period has given rise to a regime which claims to defend 'genuine Russian values', while in fact there is nothing behind this new traditionalism but the negation of Western hegemony. Trying to 'defend' the nation from the postulated threat of Western interventionism, the regime engages in a disavowal of politics and thus suppresses popular subjectivity. The only political subject that remains on the horizon of Russian politics is the West, while the Russian people, as any other subaltern, are being spoken for, and thus silenced, by the country's Eurocentric elites and the Western intellectuals"--</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VCentral and Eastern European perspectives on international relations series.</relation> 
<availlibrary>$$INDU$$LHESB$$1General Collection$$2(DK 510.764 .M673 2015 )$$Savailable$$31$$40$$5N$$61$$XNDU50$$YHESB$$ZGEN</availlibrary> 
<lds02>ndu_aleph003890367</lds02> 
<lds03>1. The Postcolonial and the Imperial in the Space and Time of World Politics -- 2. Russia in/and Europe : Sources of Ambiguity -- 3. Material Dependency : Postcolonialism, Development and Russia's "Backwardness" -- 4. Normative Dependency : Putinite Paleoconservatism and the Missing Peasant -- 5. The People are Speechless : Russia, the West and the Voice of the Subaltern.</lds03> 
<lds30>Central and Eastern European perspectives on international relations series.</lds30>

<search>
<creatorcontrib>Viatcheslav,  Morozov  author.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Morozov, Vauthor.</creatorcontrib> 
<creatorcontrib>Viatcheslav Morozov, Professor of EU-Russia studies, University of Tartu, Estonia.</creatorcontrib> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia's&lt;/span> postcolonial identity : a subaltern empire in a Eurocentric world /</title> 
<description>"This book applies postcolonial theory to Russia by looking at it as a subaltern empire. It pushes postcolonial studies and constructivist international relations towards an uneasy dialogue, which produces tensions and reveals multiple blind spots in both approaches. A critical re-evaluation of the existing literature enables the author to produce a comprehensive account of how Russia's position in the international system has conditioned its domestic development, and how this in turn generated specific foreign policy outcomes. Having internalised the Eurocentric worldview, Russia is nevertheless different from the core European countries. This difference is not determined by 'culture', but rather by uneven and combined development of global capitalism, in which Russia is integrated as a semi-peripheral nation. The Russian state has colonised its own periphery on behalf of the Western core, but has never been able to overcome economic and normative dependency on the West. The peculiar dialectic of the subaltern and the imperial during the post-Soviet period has given rise to a regime which claims to defend 'genuine Russian values', while in fact there is nothing behind this new traditionalism but the negation of Western hegemony. Trying to 'defend' the nation from the postulated threat of Western interventionism, the regime engages in a disavowal of politics and thus suppresses popular subjectivity. The only political subject that remains on the horizon of Russian politics is the West, while the Russian people, as any other subaltern, are being spoken for, and thus silenced, by the country's Eurocentric elites and the Western intellectuals"-- Provided by publisher.</description>

<toc>1. The Postcolonial and the Imperial in the Space and Time of World Politics -- 2. Russia in/and Europe : Sources of Ambiguity -- 3. Material Dependency : Postcolonialism, Development and Russia's "Backwardness" -- 4. Normative Dependency : Putinite Paleoconservatism and the Missing Peasant -- 5. The People are Speechless : Russia, the West and the Voice of the Subaltern.</toc>

<btitle>Russia's postcolonial identity : a subaltern empire in a Eurocentric world</btitle> 
<seriestitle>Central and Eastern European perspectives on international relations series</seriestitle> 
<date>2015</date> 
<risdate>2015.</risdate> 
<isbn>9781137409294</isbn> 
<isbn>1137409290</isbn> 
<format>book</format> 
<ristype>BOOK</ristype> 
<notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes> 
<abstract>"This book applies postcolonial theory to Russia by looking at it as a subaltern empire. It pushes postcolonial studies and constructivist international relations towards an uneasy dialogue, which produces tensions and reveals multiple blind spots in both approaches. A critical re-evaluation of the existing literature enables the author to produce a comprehensive account of how Russia's position in the international system has conditioned its domestic development, and how this in turn generated specific foreign policy outcomes. Having internalised the Eurocentric worldview, Russia is nevertheless different from the core European countries. This difference is not determined by 'culture', but rather by uneven and combined development of global capitalism, in which Russia is integrated as a semi-peripheral nation. The Russian state has colonised its own periphery on behalf of the Western core, but has never been able to overcome economic and normative dependency on the West. The peculiar dialectic of the subaltern and the imperial during the post-Soviet period has given rise to a regime which claims to defend 'genuine Russian values', while in fact there is nothing behind this new traditionalism but the negation of Western hegemony. Trying to 'defend' the nation from the postulated threat of Western interventionism, the regime engages in a disavowal of politics and thus suppresses popular subjectivity. The only political subject that remains on the horizon of Russian politics is the West, while the Russian people, as any other subaltern, are being spoken for, and thus silenced, by the country's Eurocentric elites and the Western intellectuals"--</abstract>

<control>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
<sourcerecordid>$$V002447747$$Ondu_aleph002447747</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$VMIU01-006805583$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V002433868$$Ondu_aleph002433868</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph002447747</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vhathi_pub$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph002433868</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg16349082</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph002447747</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VHATHI$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph002433868</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph002447747</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph002433868</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph002447747</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph002433868</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01002447747$$Ondu_aleph002447747</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VHATHIMIU01-006805583$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01002433868$$Ondu_aleph002433868</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> and arms control are there opportunities for the Obama Administration?</title> 
<creator>Stephen J. Blank</creator> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle, Pa. : Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</publisher> 
<creationdate>2009</creationdate> 
<format>xii, 173 p. : digital, PDF file..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1584873817; $$CISBN $$V9781584873815</identifier> 
<subject>Nuclear arms control -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Nuclear arms control -- United States</subject> 
<subject>Diplomacy</subject> 
<subject>Negotiation</subject> 
<subject>Security, International</subject> 
<subject>Arms control -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Arms control -- United States</subject> 
<subject>United States -- Military relations -- Russia [Federation]</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Military relations -- United States</subject> 
<description>Russo-American relations are generally acknowledged to be at an impasse. Arms control issues feature prominently in that conflicted agenda. Since the outbreak of the Russo-Georgian war in August 2008, both [Russia and the U.S.] have further hardened positions and raised tensions apart from the war itself and Russia's quite evident refusal to abide by its own cease-fire terms. Nevertheless, and for better or worse, arms control and its agenda will remain at the heart of the bilateral Russo-American relationship for a long time. Arms control and disarmament issues are quintessentially political as well as military issues that are among the most critical components of the bilateral relationship and regional security in both Europe and Asia. For these reasons, neither the political nor the military aspect can be divorced from the other. And for these same reasons, we cannot refuse to participate in the bilateral effort to resolve those issues.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

<search><creatorcontrib>Stephen J.  Blank</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Blank, S</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Stephen J. Blank.</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Army War College (U.S.). <delivery><institution>$$VNDU$$Ondu_aleph002447747</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ondu_aleph002447747</delcategory><institution>$$VMALC$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</institution><institution>$$VNDU$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ohathi_pubMIU01-006805583</delcategory><institution>$$VNDU$$Ondu_aleph002433868</institution><delcategory>$$VOnline Resource$$Ondu_aleph002433868</delcategory></delivery>

<addata><aulast>Blank</aulast><aufirst>Stephen J.</aufirst><au>Blank, Stephen J</au><btitle>Russia and arms control are there opportunities for the Obama Administration?</btitle><date>2009</date><risdate>2009]</risdate><isbn>1584873817</isbn><isbn>9781584873815</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references (p. 140-172).</notes><abstract>Russo-American relations are generally acknowledged to be at an impasse. Arms control issues feature prominently in that conflicted agenda. Since the outbreak of the Russo-Georgian war in August 2008, both [Russia and the U.S.] have further hardened positions and raised tensions apart from the war itself and Russia's quite evident refusal to abide by its own cease-fire terms. Nevertheless, and for better or worse, arms control and its agenda will remain at the heart of the bilateral Russo-American relationship for a long time. Arms control and disarmament issues are quintessentially political as well as military issues that are among the most critical components of the bilateral relationship and regional security in both Europe and Asia. For these reasons, neither the political nor the military aspect can be divorced from the other. And for these same reasons, we cannot refuse to participate in the bilateral effort to resolve those issues.</abstract><cop>Carlisle, Pa.]</cop><pub>Strategic Studies Institute, [U.S. Army War College</pub><oclcid>315616160</oclcid><aufirst>Stephen,</aufirst><au>Blank, Stephen</au><btitle>Russia and arms control : are there opportunities for the Obama Administration?</btitle><risdate>[2009]</risdate><cop>Carlisle, PA</cop><pub>Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</pub><oclcid>316549605</oclcid><risdate>2009.</risdate><notes>Includes bibliographical references: p. 140-172.</notes></addata>

<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia's&lt;/span> dangerous texts politics between the lines</title> 
<creator>Kathleen. Parthé</creator> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor>

<creationdate>c2004</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xix, 283 p.).</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780300138221 (electronic bk.); $$CISBN $$V0300138229 (electronic bk.); $$CISBN $$V0300098510 (cloth : alk. paper); $$CISBN $$V9780300098518 (cloth : alk. paper)</identifier> 
<subject>Russian literature -- Political aspects</subject> 
<subject>Politics and literature -- Russia</subject> 
<subject>Politics and literature -- Soviet Union</subject> 
<subject>Politics in literature</subject> 
<subject>Nationalism in literature</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>Kathleen F. Parthé offers a compelling analysis of the power of Russian literature to shape national identity despite sustained efforts to silence authors deemed subversive.</description>

<sourcerecordid>$$V003975528$$Ondu_aleph003975528</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V000150746$$Obci_aleph000150746</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V003883667$$Ondu_aleph003883667</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003975528</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vbci_aleph$$Obci_aleph000150746</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003883667</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg142942196</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003975528</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VBCI01$$Obci_aleph000150746</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003883667</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003975528</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Obci_aleph000150746</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003883667</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003975528</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Obci_aleph000150746</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003883667</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003975528$$Ondu_aleph003975528</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VBCI01000150746$$Obci_aleph000150746</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003883667$$Ondu_aleph003883667</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>Everyday life in &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> past and present</title> 
<contributor>Karen Petrone</contributor> 
<contributor>Mary W. Cavender 1966-</contributor> 
<contributor>David L Ransel</contributor> 
<contributor>Choi Chatterjee</contributor> 
<contributor>Project Muse.</contributor> 
<publisher>Bloomington : Indiana University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>2014</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource.</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780253012609; $$CISBN $$V0253012600</identifier> 
<subject>Interpersonal relations -- Russia [Federation] -- History -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Interpersonal relations -- Soviet Union -- History -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Interpersonal relations -- Russia -- History -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Social conditions -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Soviet Union -- Social conditions -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Social conditions -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- Social life and customs -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Soviet Union -- Social life and customs -- Congresses</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Social life and customs -- Congresses</subject> 
<description>"In these original essays on long-term patterns of everyday life in pre-revolutionary, Soviet, and contemporary Russia, distinguished scholars survey the cultural practices, power relations, and behaviors that characterized daily existence for Russians through the post-Soviet present. Microanalyses and transnational perspectives shed new light on the formation and elaboration of gender, ethnicity, class, nationalism, and subjectivity. Changes in consumption and communication patterns, the restructuring of familial and social relations, systems of cultural meanings, and evolving practices in the home, at the workplace, and at sites of leisure are among the topics explored"--</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VIndiana-Michigan series in Russian and East European studies.</relation> 
 
 
 
 
<availlibrary>$$IBCI$$LBCI$$1Main Collection$$2(DK 32 .E776 2014 )$$Savailable$$31$$40$$5N$$60$$XBCI50$$YBCI$$ZMAIN$$Obci_aleph000150746</availlibrary><availinstitution>$$IBCI$$Savailable</availinstitution><availpnx>available</availpnx><lds01>Papers from an interdisciplinary workshop entitled "Everyday Life in Russia and the Soviet Union," held in May 2010 on Indiana University's Bloomington campus.</lds01><lds01>Gift of the Jack Detzler Library Endowment. (2015)</lds01><lds02>ndu_aleph003975528</lds02><lds02>bci_aleph000150746</lds02><lds02>ndu_aleph003883667</lds02><lds03>Introduction: The Genesis and Themes of Everyday Life in Russia Past and Present -- Part I. Approaches to Everyday Life -- 1. The Scholarship of Everyday Life / David L. Ransel -- 2. Provincial Nobles, Elite History, and the Imagination of Everyday Life / Mary Cavender -- 3. Resisting Resistance : Everyday Life, Practical Competence, and Neoliberal Rhetoric in Postsocialist Russia / Olga Shevchenko -- 4. The Oil Company and the Crafts Fair : From Povsednevnost' to Byt in Postsocialist Russia / Douglas Rogers -- Part II. Public Identities and Public Space -- 5. "We Don't Talk about Ourselves" : Women Academics Recall Their Path to Success / Natalia Pushkareva -- 6. The Literature of Everyday Life and Popular Representations of Motherhood in Brezhnev's Time / Elizabeth Skomp -- 7. "They Are Taking That Air from Us" : Sale of Commonly Enjoyed Properties to Private Developers / David L. Ransel -- Part III. Living Space and Personal Choice -- 8. Everyday Life and the Problem of Conceptualizing Public and Private during the Khrushchev Era / Deborah A. Field -- 9. Soviet Mass Housing and the Communist Way of Life / Steven E. Harris -- 10. Everyday Aesthetics in the Khrushchev-Era Standard Apartment / Susan E. Reid -- 11. The Post-Soviet Kommunalka : Continuity and Difference? / Ilya Utekhin -- Part IV. Myth, Memory, and the History of Everyday Life -- 12. Everyday Stalinism in Transition-Era Film / Peter C. Pozefsky -- 13. Totality Decomposed : Objectalizing Late Socialism in Post-Soviet Biochronicles / Serguei Oushakine -- 14. Everyday Life and the Ties That Bind in Liudmila Ulitskaia's Medea and Her Children / Benjamin Sutcliffe -- Part V. Coming Home : Transnational Connections -- 15. Sino-Soviet Every Day : Chinese Revolutionaries in Moscow Military Schools, 1927-1930 / Elizabeth McGuire -- 16. Coming Home Soviet Style : The Reintegration of Afghan Veterans into Soviet Everyday Life / Karen Petrone -- 17. Everyday Life in Transnational Perspective : Consumption and Consumerism, 1917-1939 / Choi Chatterjee -- Afterword / Sheila Fitzpatrick.</lds03><lds30>Indiana-Michigan series in Russian and East European studies</lds30><lds30>Indiana-Michigan series in Russian and East European studies.</lds30></display>

<addata><aulast>Petrone</aulast><aufirst>Karen.</aufirst><isbn>0253012600</isbn><cop>Bloomington</cop><pub>Indiana University Press</pub><aulast>Chatterjee</aulast><aufirst>Choi.</aufirst><addau>Chatterjee, Choi</addau><addau>Ransel, David L</addau><addau>Cavender, Mary W.</addau><addau>Petrone, Karen</addau><btitle>Everyday life in Russia past and present</btitle><seriestitle>Indiana-Michigan series in Russian and East European studies</seriestitle><date>2014</date><risdate>2014.</risdate><isbn>9780253012456</isbn><isbn>0253012457</isbn><isbn>9780253012548</isbn><isbn>0253012546</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references.</notes><abstract>"In these original essays on long-term patterns of everyday life in pre-revolutionary, Soviet, and contemporary Russia, distinguished scholars survey the cultural practices, power relations, and behaviors that characterized daily existence for Russians through the post-Soviet present. Microanalyses and transnational perspectives shed new light on the formation and elaboration of gender, ethnicity, class, nationalism, and subjectivity. Changes in consumption and communication patterns, the restructuring of familial and social relations, systems of cultural meanings, and evolving practices in the home, at the workplace, and at sites of leisure are among the topics explored"--</abstract><oclcid>852457665</oclcid><lccn>2014020094</lccn><aulast>Fitzpatrick</aulast><aufirst>Sheila,</aufirst><addau>Fitzpatrick, Sheila</addau><date>2015</date><risdate>2015.</risdate><isbn>9780253012609</isbn><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes></addata>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>, 1762-1825 military power, the state, and the people</title> 
<creator>Janet M. Hartley</creator> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor> 
<publisher>Westport, Conn. : Praeger</publisher> 
<creationdate>2008</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (viii, 318 pages)..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780313352324; $$CISBN $$V0313352321</identifier> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- History, Military -- 18th century</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- History, Military -- 19th century</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>A study of the Russian Empire at the peak of its. military power and success (1762-1825), this important. book examines how a country with none of the obvious. trappings of modernization was able to significantly. expand its territory. Russia's military and naval. victories culminated in the triumphal entrance of. Russian forces into Paris in 1814 in celebration of the. defeat of Napoleon. Hartley's treatment is wide-ranging. and discusses many aspects of the nature of the Russian. state and society-not merely issues such as recruitment, . but also institutional, legal, and fiscal structures of.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VStudies in military history and international affairs. 1537-4432</relation> 
<rights>Restrictions unspecified</rights>

<sourcerecordid>$$V000124669$$Obci_aleph000124669</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V002507238$$Ondu_aleph002507238</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vbci_aleph$$Obci_aleph000124669</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph002507238</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg32880317</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VBCI01$$Obci_aleph000124669</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph002507238</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Obci_aleph000124669</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph002507238</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Obci_aleph000124669</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph002507238</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VBCI01000124669$$Obci_aleph000124669</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01002507238$$Ondu_aleph002507238</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>A history of modern &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> : from tsarism to the twenty-first century</title> 
<creator>Robert Service 1947-</creator> 
<contributor>Robert Service 1947-</contributor> 
<edition>3rd ed..</edition> 
<publisher>Cambridge, Mass. : Harvard University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>c2009</creationdate> 
<format>xli, 687 p. : ill., maps ; 21 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9780674034938 (pbk.); $$CISBN $$V0674034937 (pbk.)</identifier> 
<subject>Soviet Union -- History</subject> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- History -- 1991-</subject> 
<description>From the Publisher: Russia had an extraordinary twentieth century, undergoing upheaval and transformation. Updating his acclaimed History of Modern Russia, Robert Service provides a panoramic perspective on a country whose Soviet past encompassed revolution, civil war, mass terror, and two world wars. He shows how seven decades of communist rule, which penetrated every aspect of Soviet life, continue to influence Russia today. This new edition takes the story from 2002 through the entire presidency of Vladimir Putin to the election of his successor, Dmitri Medvedev.</description> 
<language>eng</language>

<addata><abstract>From the Publisher: Russia had an extraordinary twentieth century, undergoing upheaval and transformation. Updating his acclaimed History of Modern Russia, Robert Service provides a panoramic perspective on a country whose Soviet past encompassed revolution, civil war, mass terror, and two world wars. He shows how seven decades of communist rule, which penetrated every aspect of Soviet life, continue to influence Russia today. This new edition takes the story from 2002 through the entire presidency of Vladimir Putin to the election of his successor, Dmitri Medvedev.</abstract><aulast>Service</aulast><aufirst>Robert,</aufirst><au>Service, Robert</au><addau>Service, Robert</addau><btitle>A history of modern Russia : from tsarism to the twenty-first century</btitle><date>2009</date><risdate>c2009.</risdate><isbn>9780674034938</isbn><isbn>0674034937</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><cop>Cambridge, Mass.</cop><pub>Harvard University Press</pub><oclcid>313018454</oclcid><lccn>2009009639</lccn></addata>

<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>The modernisation of &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>, 1676-1825</title> 
<creator>Simon Dixon [Simon M.]</creator> 
<contributor>EBSCO Publishing [Firm]</contributor> 
<publisher>Cambridge ; New York : Cambridge University Press</publisher> 
<creationdate>1999</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xvii, 267 pages) : maps..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V051101905X; $$CISBN $$V9780511019050; $$CISBN $$V0511037244; $$CISBN $$V9780511037245; $$CISBN $$V051115058X; $$CISBN $$V9780511150586; $$CISBN $$V0511115962; $$CISBN $$V9780511115967; $$CISBN $$V9780521379618; $$CISBN $$V052137961X; $$CISBN $$V9780521371001; $$CISBN $$V0521371007; $$CISBN $$V9780511818585; $$CISBN $$V0511818580</identifier> 
<subject>Russia [Federation] -- History -- 1613-1917</subject> 
<subject>Electronic books</subject> 
<description>"This is the first book to place Russia's 'long' eighteenth century squarely in its European context. The conceptual framework is set out in an opening critique of modernisation theory which, while rejecting its linear implications, maintains its focus on the relationship between government, economy, and society. Following a chronological introduction, a series of thematic chapters emphasise the ways in which Russia's international ambitions as an emerging great power provoked administrative and fiscal reforms with wide-ranging (and often unanticipated) social consequences."--Jacket.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VNew approaches to European history</relation> 
<relation>$$Cvar_title $$VModernization of Russia, 1676-1825</relation>

<search><creatorcontrib>Simon  Dixon  (Simon M.)</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Dixon, S</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>Simon Dixon.</creatorcontrib><creatorcontrib>EBSCO Publishing (Firm)</creatorcontrib><title>The modernisation of &lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span>, 1676-1825</title><description>"This is the first book to place Russia's 'long' eighteenth century squarely in its European context. The conceptual framework is set out in an opening critique of modernisation theory which, while rejecting its linear implications, maintains its focus on the relationship between government, economy, and society. Following a chronological introduction, a series of thematic chapters emphasise the ways in which Russia's international ambitions as an emerging great power provoked administrative and fiscal reforms with wide-ranging (and often unanticipated) social consequences."--Jacket.</description><subject>Russia (Federation) History 1613-1917.</subject><subject>Electronic books.</subject><general>Cambridge <addata><aulast>Dixon</aulast><aufirst>Simon</aufirst><au>Dixon, Simon</au><btitle>The modernisation of Russia, 1676-1825</btitle><addtitle>Modernization of Russia, 1676-1825</addtitle><seriestitle>New approaches to European history</seriestitle><date>1999</date><risdate>1999.</risdate><isbn>051101905X</isbn><isbn>9780511019050</isbn><isbn>0511037244</isbn><isbn>9780511037245</isbn><isbn>051115058X</isbn><isbn>9780511150586</isbn><isbn>0511115962</isbn><isbn>9780511115967</isbn><isbn>9780521379618</isbn><isbn>052137961X</isbn><isbn>9780521371001</isbn><isbn>0521371007</isbn><isbn>9780511818585</isbn><isbn>0511818580</isbn><format>book</format><ristype>BOOK</ristype><notes>Includes bibliographical references and index.</notes><abstract>"This is the first book to place Russia's 'long' eighteenth century squarely in its European context. The conceptual framework is set out in an opening critique of modernisation theory which, while rejecting its linear implications, maintains its focus on the relationship between government, economy, and society. Following a chronological introduction, a series of thematic chapters emphasise the ways in which Russia's international ambitions as an emerging great power provoked administrative and fiscal reforms with wide-ranging (and often unanticipated) social consequences."--Jacket.</abstract><cop>Cambridge ; New York</cop><pub>Cambridge University Press</pub><oclcid>51296807</oclcid><oclcid>40061361</oclcid><lccn>98046739</lccn><seriestitle>Academic Complete (ebrary)</seriestitle></addata>

<sourcerecordid>$$V004452355$$Ondu_aleph004452355</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V003073765$$Ondu_aleph003073765</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph004452355</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003073765</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg75316020</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph004452355</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003073765</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph004452355</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003073765</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph004452355</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003073765</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01004452355$$Ondu_aleph004452355</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003073765$$Ondu_aleph003073765</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia&lt;/span> before the radiant future : essays in modern history, culture, and society</title> 
<creator>Michael Confino 1926-2010.</creator> 
<contributor>JSTOR [Organization].</contributor> 
<publisher>New York : Berghahn Books</publisher> 
<creationdate>2011</creationdate> 
<format>1 online resource (xiii, 296 pages).</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V9781845459932 (electronic bk.) (discovery); $$CISBN $$V1845459938 (electronic bk.) (discovery)</identifier> 
<subject>Enlightenment</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Historiography</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Intellectual life</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Relations -- Western countries</subject> 
<subject>Western countries -- Relations -- Russia</subject> 
<subject>Russia -- Social conditions</subject> 
<description>One of the major historians of prerevolutionary Russia has collected in this volume some of his most important essays. Written over a number of years, these pioneering works have been revised and updated and are complemented by others being published for the first time. Thematically, they cover major subjects in Imperial Russian history and in historical writing, such as ideas and their role in historical change; the intelligentsia, the nobility, and peasant society; and historiography. The twelve essays raise cardinal questions about current scholarship on Russian history before the upheavals.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
 
 
 
<availlibrary>$$INDU$$LHESB$$1General Collection$$2(DK 38 .C66 2011 )$$Sunavailable$$31$$41$$5N$$60$$XNDU50$$YHESB$$ZGEN$$Ondu_aleph003073765</availlibrary><availinstitution>$$INDU$$Sunavailable</availinstitution><availpnx>unavailable</availpnx><lds01>JSTOR Books at JSTOR Demand Driven Acquisitions</lds01><lds01>Made available by: The Marshall Fund for Eastern Europe and Soviet Culture.</lds01><lds02>ndu_aleph004452355</lds02><lds02>ndu_aleph003073765</lds02><lds03>The discipline and I -- pt. 1. The fate of ideas in history -- Alexander Herzen and Isaiah Berlin on Russia's elusive counter-Enlightenment -- Russian and Western European roots of Soviet totalitarianism -- Traditions, old and new : patterns of protest and dissent in modern Russia -- pt. 2. Social groups in comparative perspective -- On intellectuals and intellectual traditions in eighteenth- and nineteenth- century Russia -- The nobility in Russia and Western Europe : contrasts and similarities -- Comparing Russian serfdom and American slavery -- Agrarian crisis, urbanization, and the Russian peasants at the end of the old regime, 1880s-1920s -- pt. 3. Approaches to the history of Russia -- Re-inventing the Enlightenment : Western images and Eastern realities in the eighteenth century -- Political murder in Russian culture : comparisons and counterfactuals -- Current events and the representation of the past : issues in Russian historical writing -- Afterword.</lds03><lds03>The discipline and I -- The fate of ideas in history. Alexander Herzen and Isaiah Berlin on Russia's elusive counter-Enlightenment ; Russian and Western European roots of Soviet totalitarianism ; Traditions, old and new : patterns of protest and dissent in modern Russia -- Social groups in comparative perspective. On intellectuals and intellectual traditions in eighteenth- and nineteenth- century Russia ; The nobility in Russia and Western Europe : contrasts and similarities ; Comparing Russian serfdom and American slavery ; Agrarian crisis, urbanization, and the Russian peasants at the end of the old regime, 1880s-1920s -- Approaches to the history of Russia. Re-inventing the Enlightenment : Western images and Eastern realities in the eighteenth century ; Political murder in Russian culture : comparisons and counterfactuals ; Current events and the representation of the past : issues in Russian historical writing.</lds03></display>

<sourcerecordid>$$V003379942$$Ondu_aleph003379942</sourcerecordid><sourcerecordid>$$V003382613$$Ondu_aleph003382613</sourcerecordid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003379942</sourceid><sourceid>$$Vndu_aleph$$Ondu_aleph003382613</sourceid><recordid>dedupmrg86022509</recordid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003379942</originalsourceid><originalsourceid>$$VNDU01$$Ondu_aleph003382613</originalsourceid><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003379942</sourceformat><sourceformat>$$VMARC21$$Ondu_aleph003382613</sourceformat><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003379942</sourcesystem><sourcesystem>$$VAleph$$Ondu_aleph003382613</sourcesystem><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003379942$$Ondu_aleph003379942</ilsapiid><ilsapiid>$$VNDU01003382613$$Ondu_aleph003382613</ilsapiid></control>
<display>
<type>book</type> 
<title>&lt;span class="searchword">Russia's&lt;/span> homegrown insurgency : jihad in the North Caucasus</title> 
<contributor>Army War College [U.S.]. Strategic Studies Institute.</contributor> 
<publisher>Carlisle, PA : Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College</publisher> 
<creationdate>2012</creationdate> 
<format>vi, 157 p. ; 23 cm..</format> 
<identifier>$$CISBN $$V1584875445; $$CISBN $$V9781584875444</identifier> 
<subject>Jihad</subject> 
<subject>Insurgency -- Russia [Federation] -- Caucasus, Northern</subject> 
<subject>Counterinsurgency -- Russia [Federation] -- Caucasus, Northern</subject> 
<subject>Islamic fundamentalism -- Russia [Federation] -- Caucasus, Northern</subject> 
<subject>Internal security -- Russia [Federation] -- Caucasus, Northern</subject> 
<subject>Caucasus, Northern [Russia] -- Politics and government -- 21st century</subject> 
<subject>Caucasus, Northern [Russia] -- Strategic aspects</subject> 
<description>The three papers offered in this monograph provide a detailed analysis of the insurgency and counterinsurgency campaigns being conducted by Islamist rebels against Russia in the North Caucasus. This conflict is Russia's primary security threat, but it has barely registered on Western minds and is hardly reported in the West as well. To overcome this neglect, these three papers go into great detail concerning the nature of the Islamist challenge, the Russian response, and the implications of this conflict. This monograph, in keeping with SSI's objectives, provides a basis for dialogue among U.S., European, and Russian experts concerning insurgency and counterinsurgency, which will certainly prove useful to all of these nations, since they will continue to be challenged by such wars well into the future. It is important for us to learn from the insurgency in the North Caucasus, because the issues raised by this conflict will not easily go away, even for the United States as it leaves Afghanistan.</description> 
<language>eng</language> 
<relation>$$Cseries $$VSSI monograph.</relation>

Cornell.</lds03><lds30>SSI monograph.</lds30></display>

To overcome this neglect, these three papers go into great detail concerning the nature of the Islamist challenge, the Russian response, and the implications of this conflict. This monograph, in keeping with SSI's objectives, provides a basis for dialogue among U.S., European, and Russian experts concerning insurgency and counterinsurgency, which will certainly prove useful to all of these nations, since they will continue to be challenged by such wars well into the future. </record></PrimoNMBib><sear:GETIT deliveryCategory="Online Resource" GetIt1="http://www.strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pubs/download.cfm?q=1116"
